technology companies weigh on the broader market. Investors have shown some caution, buying into U.S. Treasuries, in front of an appearance from Fed Chair Powell at the top of the hour.The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.9%. The Russell 2000 is up 0.1% after underperforming yesterday.Mr. Powell's position as Fed Chair usually commands the most attention, but the market has taken a leg lower in recent action after St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC voter) said a half-point cut in the fed funds rate would be too much. Instead, Mr. Bullard prefers a quarter-point cut.Economic data released today has provided some insight into the housing sector and consumer sentiment that has also disappointed investors. New homes sales declined 7.8% m/m in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 626,000 (Briefing.com consensus 683,000), and the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index fell to 121.5 in June (Briefing.com consensus 132.0).Today's action has been largely risk-off, which is being reflected across losses in nine of the 11 S&P 500 sectors. Leading today's retreat are the S&P 500 communication services (-1.4%), information technology (-1.2%), and consumer discretionary (-0.7%) sectors. The materials (+0.1%) and real estate (+0.02%) sectors cling onto slim gains.Home construction company Lennar (LEN 48.33, -3.13, -6.1%) has also contributed to the cautious sentiment after it issued downside Q3 guidance, discouraging investors after it provided positive quarterly results earlier in the day.Separately, there has been a mega-merger deal in the health care space. Allergan (AGN 164.00, +34.41, +26.6%) confirmed it will be acquired by pharmaceutical company AbbVie (ABBV 66.33, -12.12, -15.5%) for about $63 billion, or $188.24 per share, in cash and stock. With shares of AbbVie currently down over 15%, the deal represents a 37% premium to AGN's closing price on Monday.U.S. Treasuries have advanced, pushing the benchmark 10-yr yield down three basis points to 1.99%, as investors remain cautious about the economic outlook. The U.S. Dollar Index is up 0.2% to 96.21.Reviewing today's batch of economic data:The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index fell to 121.5 in June (Briefing.com consensus 132.0) from a downwardly revised 131.3 (from 134.1) in May. The index is at its lowest level since September 2017.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects growing concern about trade tensions among consumers that had been previously lacking, but which had been showing up in business confidence surveys. Flagging confidence on the part of businesses and consumers alike, if it is sustained, is an adverse development for the growth outlook.New home sales declined 7.8% m/m in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 626,000 (Briefing.com consensus 683,000) from an upwardly revised 679,000 (from 673,000) in April.The key takeaway from the report is that demand was relatively soft despite a drop in mortgage rates and a 2.8% yr/yr decline in the median sales price of $308,000.The FHFA Housing Price Index for April increased 0.4% (Briefing.com consensus 0.2%) following an unrevised 0.1% increase in March. The S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for April increased 2.5% as expected after increasing a revised 2.6% in March (from 2.7%).12:48TALKX Market Briefing: Bullard reins in scope of rate-cut expectationsThe stock market has hit an air pocket, moving to its lows for the session, following comments from St. Louis Fed President Bullard (FOMC voter) who said he sees a rate cut coming in July, but that he doesn't think a 50-basis points rate cut is necessary.This remark caused some knee-jerk selling interest, as there has been a growing belief that the Fed will be inclined to cut the target range for the fed funds rate by 50 basis points at its July 30-31 FOMC meeting. The fact that one of the Fed's biggest doves -- if not the biggest -- is seemingly trying to rein in the market's rate-cut hopes has taken some of that rate-cut premium out of stock prices.As a reminder, Fed Chair Powell has a speaking engagement at 1:00 p.m. ET.The Russell 2000 is down 0.2%; the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.5%; the S&P 500 is down 0.6%; and the Nasdaq Composite is down 1.0%.12:00MSFT Microsoft hit by profit-taking interest (134.79 -2.99)Shares of Dow component Microsoft (MSFT 134.56, -3.22, -2.3%), which is also the largest stock by market capitalization, are underperforming today. That has to do in large part with how the stock has outperformed since June 3.Entering today, Microsoft was up 15% since June 3 (i.e. the day before Fed Chair Powell said the Fed would act appropriately to sustain the expansion) versus a 7.3% gain for the S&P 500 and a 9.2% gain for the Nasdaq Composite.A 15% move in a stock the size of Microsoft is a massive move and left shares of MSFT 21% above their 200-day moving average. The basis for today's selling, then, is a pullback from a short-term overbought condition.That condition was brought to light today by the analyst at Jefferies who raised his price target to $90 from $80, but maintained an Underperform rating and called the stock "materially overvalued."It won't be lost on investors that MSFT has defied the Jefferies view of the stock's prospects in a big way leading into today; nonetheless, with the broader market in a consolidation mode in front of the G-20 summit, the Jefferies view today looks to have served as another profit-taking catalyst.11:45SUMRX European Markets Update: DAX -0.27%, FTSE +0.13%, CAC -0.05%---Equity Markets---STOXX Europe 600: -0.03%Germany's DAX: -0.27%U.K.'s FTSE 100: +0.13%France's CAC 40: -0.05%Italy's FTSE MIB: -0.73%Spain's IBEX 35: -0.24%11:41SCANX Small cap notable movers of interest -- Xencor (XNCR) rises on addition to S&P SmallCap 600 index -Technical-The following are some of today's most notable small cap movers of interest ($300 mln - $2 bln market cap), ranked by % change (all stocks over 100K average daily volume).Small Cap GainersXNCR (38.25 +12.92%): Co will take the place of HFF Inc. The results included data from the company's Phase 2/3 OSPREY trial in men with high risk and metastatic prostate cancer and three presentations from an investigator-sponsored study conducted under the company's PyL Research Access Program that evaluated PyL in men with biochemically recurrent prostate cancer. Collectively, the data presented highlights the potential of PyL to detect locally advanced prostate cancer, biochemically recurrent prostate cancer, and metastatic disease. ANI Pharma (ANIP) announced the launch of Ranitidine Capsules, 150mg and 300mg. The current annual US market for this product is approx. $40 mln, according to Iqvia/IMS Health.Tricida (TCDA) announced that The Lancet published online detailed results from its long-term, Phase 3, multicenter, placebo-controlled trial, TRCA-301E, in 196 patients with chronic kidney disease and metabolic acidosis.TILT Biotherapeutics, a company working in the area of enabling tumor T-cell therapies and checkpoint inhibiting antibodies with oncolytic viruses, has entered into an agreement with Merck KGaA, Darmstadt (MKKGY) and Pfizer (PFE) to evaluate its armed oncolytic virus, TILT-123, with avelumab in patients with solid tumors refractory to routine modalities.Halozyme Therapeutics (HALO) announced a Cooperative Research and Development Agreement with the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases' Vaccine Research Center (VRC) enabling the VRC's use of Halozyme's ENHANZE drug delivery technology to develop subcutaneous formulations of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs) against HIV for HIV treatment. The two bnAbs selected for the CRADA are VRC07-523LS and N6LS.Bausch Health (BHC) put in notice to pay down an additional $100 mln of its senior secured term loans this week, using cash generated from operations. The proxy access bylaw provisions permit a shareholder, or a group of up to twenty shareholders, who have held three percent or more of the Company's stock for at least three years, to nominate and include in the Company's annual proxy materials director nominees constituting the greater of twenty percent or two members of the Company's Board of Directors, provided that the shareholders and nominees satisfy the requirements specified in the Company's Bylaws.IHG (IHG) and Sands China (SCHYY) announced that The Venetian Macao and The Parisian Macao will become InterContinental Alliance Resorts beginning today. This will be the single largest sale of gas contract in the history of the newly merged Linde and of its legacy companies.07:05FDS FactSet beats by $0.25, beats on revs; raises FY19 EPS guidance; narrows FY19 revenue guidance (293.33 )Reports Q3 (May) earnings of $2.62 per share, excluding non-recurring items, $0.25 better than the S&P Capital IQ Consensus of $2.37; revenues rose 7.2% year/year to $364.5 mln vs the $359.25 mln S&P Capital IQ Consensus.ASV plus professional services was $1.45 bln at May 31, 2019. Organic ASV, which excludes the effects of acquisitions, dispositions and foreign currency, plus professional services, increased $4.5 mln over the last three months.Co issues raised guidance for FY19, sees EPS of $9.80-9.90 from $9.50-9.65, excluding non-recurring items, vs. $9.61 S&P Capital IQ Consensus; sees FY19 revs of $1.42-1.44 bln from $1.41-1.45 bln vs. $1.43 bln S&P Capital IQ Consensus.07:03ARVN Arvinas: FDA has cleared the company's IND for ARV-471 for the treatment of patients with locally advanced or metastatic ER positive / HER2 negative breast cancer (21.87 )Arvinas expects to initiate a Phase 1 clinical trial for ARV-471 in the third quarter of 2019. In preclinical studies, ARV-471 demonstrated near-complete ER degradation in tumor cells, induced robust tumor shrinkage when dosed as a single agent in multiple ER-driven xenograft models, and showed superior anti-tumor activity as a single agent and in combination with a CDK4/6 inhibitor when compared to a standard of care agent, fulvestrant, dosed as single agent or in combination with a CDK4/6 inhibitor. Arvinas believes the differentiated pharmacology of ARV-471, including its iterative degradation activity, has the potential to translate into meaningful clinical benefit for patients.07:02NTEC Intec Pharma announces publication of results from an earlier Phase 2 clinical study of the Accordion Pill-Carbidopa/Levodopa in Parkinson's disease patients (4.16 )The article reviews pharmacokinetic and efficacy data from the Company's phase 2, multicenter, open-label, two-way randomized crossover study that evaluated multiple dose strengths of the AP-CD/LD (50/250 mg, 50/375 mg or 50/500 mg) twice daily in one treatment period and an active comparator in the other treatment period. The article presents results from cohorts 1-4 out of the 6 cohorts of PD patients who participated in the study. Pharmacokinetics (PK) and efficacy were evaluated for AP-CD/LD compared with immediate release Carbidopa/Levodopa (IR-CD/LD). Treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) and patient- and investigator-reported measures were also evaluated. The PK results showed that compared with IR-CD/LD, treatment with either AP-CD/LD dose demonstrated more stable LD plasma concentrations in both fluctuating and non-fluctuating PD patients, and significantly decreased the LD Cmax (57.1% and 66.8% decreases among fluctuating and non-fluctuating patients, respectively).07:01ARQL ArQule prices underwritten public offering of 9.25 mln shares of its common stock at a price to the public of $9.75 per share (10.01 )07:01RMBS Rambus sells token services and ticketing businesses to Visa (V); terms not disclosed (11.55 )The combination of Visa's network tokenization capabilities with the local and account tokenization technology of Rambus will facilitate safer, more secure payments across all forms of global commerce.07:00ALDX Aldeyra Therapeutics announces results from noninfectious anterior uveitis SOLACE Trial -- statistical significance was not achieved for the primary or secondary endpoints (7.09 )Statistical significance was not achieved for the primary or secondary endpoints, due to high rates of disease resolution in vehicle-treated patients, but activity of reproxalap was consistently greater than that of vehicle. Noninfectious anterior uveitis program to be discontinued. The co plans to prioritize Phase 3 ocular pipeline programs in dry eye disease, allergic conjunctivitis, and proliferative vitreoretinopathy.07:00SUMRX Asian Markets Close: Nikkei -0.6%, Hang Seng -1.2%, Shanghai -0.9%Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Tuesday on a mostly lower note. Escalation of tariffs between the US and China falters the marketsCE Noticias Financieras EnglishMay 14, 2019 TuesdayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 812 wordsBody The trade war between the United States and China intensified yesterday, as Beijing said it would raise tariffs on 60 billion dollars of US products, which defied Donald Trump's warnings and caused a massive sale in international markets.  China's Ministry of Finance said it would increase levies on different products ranging from liquefied natural gas and frozen spinach to toothpaste, in "response to unilateralism and US trade protectionism," the way they described the decision. of the Trump administration last Friday to raise tariffs on 200 billion dollars of Chinese imports to 25 percent.  The Trump government was expected to retaliate later on Monday by releasing details of a plan to affect another 300 billion dollars in Chinese imports with tariffs of 25 percent, a measure he said last week after The trade negotiations in Washington between the US and Chinese negotiators failed to reach an agreement.  "China should not retaliate, that is only going to make things worse!" Trump tweeted before the Chinese announcement, warning Beijing that it will be "very damaged" if the trade conflict continues. "They had a great deal, almost complete, and they backed off!" He wrote.  In response, stocks fell, as investors fled to more secure assets, including government debt. All the indices of US markets registered a fall, with the S & P 500 that experienced a decline of 2.3 percent, and the Nasdaq, with a heavy load of technology companies, with a fall of 3.2 percent for the midday operations in New York. York International stocks fell to their lowest level since March, with the FTSE All World index recording a loss of 1.8 percent, its biggest one-day decline since December.  The tariff increases announced by Beijing yesterday will affect sectors ranging from heavy manufacturing and industry to agriculture and household goods. Apple's shares fell 6 percent in midday trading, while Caterpillar's declined 5 percent.  "Companies like Apple and Caterpillar have significant exposure to revenues outside the US, immediate mass sales will have an impact on these types of companies," said Kristina Hooper, head of international markets strategy at Invesco. "It is not a specific history of a sector, it is more a history of high capitalization".  Expectations in the market increased that the US Federal Reserve would respond with a reduction in interest rates. The probability of a cut before the end of the year, derived from futures prices, was 74 percent, compared to 58 percent a week ago. The yield on Treasuries fell almost 9 basis points to reach 2.18 percent, its lowest level since February 2018.  The intensification of tensions affected the currency of China and the currencies of emerging markets in general. The yuan fell 0.9 percent on its parity with the US dollar in overseas markets, after it crossed the threshold of 6.9 yuan for the first time this year. The MSCI index that tracks emerging market currencies was down 0.7 percent, putting it on track for its biggest fall of 2019.  "The confrontation now has escalated into a testosterone battle between two leaders who believe they have a lot to prove to their constituents. But as this display of machismo lasts longer, there is a greater chance of a recession, not in the US, but globally, "said Bernard Baumohl of the New York-based Economic Outlook Group.Sweater.  Beijing said that to 2 thousand 493 articles from the United States will register an increase of tariffs up to 25 percent from June 1. Among them, liquefied natural gas, agricultural products such as natural honey; compounds such as potassium sulfate, which are commonly used in fertilizers; and various manufacturing products such as LED spotlights.  In two other lists of one thousand 78 and 974 articles, tariffs will increase to 20 and 10 percent, respectively. These lists include many household products, such as toothpaste and chlorine, along with many types of clothing, equipment related to manufacturing, as well as swimming equipment for men and machinery that makes shoes.  A smaller list of 595 items will not register an increase beyond the current 5 percent level. Among these items are chemical products and industrial materials such as formaldehyde and lithium. Electronic and motorized devices, such as marches for aircraft, airplane and boat engines, and 3D printers also prevented an increase in tariffs.  "China sticks to its strategy of proportional and measured retaliation against US tariffs. The Chinese government's message is clear, it wants a resolution of the trade dispute and is willing to make concessions, but it will not shy away from a confrontation if that is the path chosen by Trump, "said Eswar Prasad, professor of international trade at the Cornell University.  With information from Don Weinland, James Politi, Joe Rennison, Richard Henderson, Pan Kwan Yuk and Nicolle Liu. Load-Date: May 14, 2019End of Document

Huawei: Trojan horse in the living room of your houseCE Noticias Financieras EnglishMay 29, 2019 WednesdayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 1448 wordsBody        Trump's accusations against Huawei could be a mere protectionist pretext. (Photo: EFE)  The "stay still" of the Trump administration against Huawei has been a tough lie against the idea of the "unstoppable" Chinese ascent, supposedly and irremediably supposed to unseat the current supremacy of the United States. It will not be like that, apparently for quite some time.  In this regard, remember that last week, with the argument of defending national security and the alleged use of spyware by Huawei to send critical data of its users to the Chinese government, the Trump administration vetoed American companies the purchase and sale of components of Huawei, a decision whose enormous impact began to be seen after the resolution of Google to cut its commercial relations with the Chinese company.  Google's initiative calls into question the viability of the company, the second largest manufacturer of cell phones in the world and the largest telecommunications company. Huawei has 180,000 employees and reaches "more than a third of the world's population" with its products, according to its website. According to the researcher Counterpoint, 17% of smartphones in the world are Huawei, only surpassed by Samsung (21%) and above Apple (12%).  Google will no longer provide Android updates or give access to its Play Store application store to the future terminals of the Chinese brand, nor will it allow the installation of such popular platforms as Gmail, Google Maps or YouTube. In addition, immediately to the blockade were joined by numerous US companies and other countries: from processor manufacturers, such as ARM, Qualcomm and Intel, to operators such as Vodafone or the Japanese NTT Docomo, Softbank and KDDI. This puts even more into question Huawei, because many of the components of their smartphones were designed on the platforms of these providers.  Now, are there any grounds to think that Huawei is a real danger to the security of the information of its users? Trump did not present a single test to support his position. In that sense, would you believe Trump just because he says so? In principle, there is a well-founded fear that the Chinese dictatorial government will force companies to have access to industrial secrets, user data and other confidential information. Recall only that China was involved for many years in many types of espionage, including cybernetics, intellectual property theft and industrial sabotage. Additionally, and for greater seriousness, the most recent Chinese laws, fundamentally the law of security of the State, force the Chinese organizations to collaborate in the national intelligence efforts.  On the other hand, the prevention against Huawei is not limited to the United States. The list of countries that have banned their technology under the same or similar assumptions is long: New Zealand, Australia, England (with restrictions), Canada, Belgium, Czech Republic, and has been put under evaluation in Germany and Japan, South Korea. In this regard, there is an undeniable concern about the participation of Chinese technology companies in security matters, specifically against Huawei.  Additionally, the accusations against Huawei for espionage are not new. Just last January an employee of his was arrested and charged in Poland in a case of industrial espionage, or, let us recall the recent arrest in Canada of Meng Wanzhou (the executive director and heiress of the company) undervarious charges by the United States, such as banking, electronic fraud, espionage and commercial relations with Iran with an extradition process under way. Or the accusations against Huawei for the same charges now, but from the Obama administration. Or in another rank, the frustrated sale of Moneygram to Alibaba, due to the refusal of a Chinese company to access data from millions of US users.  Trump's accusations against Huawei could be false and be a mere protectionist pretext to prevent the Chinese brand from having total supremacy in 5G technology, something that China has dubbed the "new silk route" and that will fundamentally decide good part of our future and its connectivity. It would not be the first time that a US government lies blatantly. Remember only the alleged chemical weapons in Iraq.  Nobody in their right mind could put their hands on the fire by Huawei or claim strictly that their terminals are free of any "back door" enabled to spy. The fear that the Chinese 5G leave a back door open and put a Trojan horse in all the rooms of the world is more than justified and has a credible background. But at the end of the day, the Chinese dictatorship would not do anything that the government of Washington did not do in complicity with Silicon Valley, as Edward Snowden revealed to us with all the harshness.  In any case, those who today protest the Trump veto conveniently forget that China imposes tougher restrictions on American companies and there has never been a protest to reject them. Thus, companies such as Google, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and others from the United States and Europe (and even Asian countries such as Japan and South Korea) have the Chinese market forbidden. Those who today protest only for Huawei have a short memory or a blatantly political agenda.  China has no respect for intellectual property and environmental laws, low costs for almost slave labor and child labor. China is also the existence of concentration camps for brainwashing, "reeducation", repression and illegal internment of part of its population. It is a hard religious persecution. There are in that country, for example, 100,000 North Korean slave workers, more than in any other country, a contemporary slavery of uprooted and unprotected people who have nowhere to go, can not leave their work, can not say no to anything, and they are not paid for it. Thus, if someone does not respect the rules of the free market are China and its companies, today alleged champions of "free competition" for some sectors.  China and the United States today are hostage to the free market, globalization and technological innovation. In any case, everything could point, as Steve Bannon suggests, to a strategy to force the Chinese government to carry out some liberalizing reforms in its economic system. In that scenario, Huawei may just be an incidental victim of his own success, but not the only one. It remains to be seen, in that sense, the Chinese response, which could be very hard too. But the truth so far and in the end is that in the hands of Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, free trade, globalization and technological innovation begin to be less themselves and more mere bureaucratic efforts at the hands of dishonest, unscrupulous politicians and ambitious.  .TF_1.ob-strip-layout .ob-widget-header {width: 100%; color: #ffffff; background: # 008ec5; padding: 6px 0px 2px 6px; font-family: \ 'notosans \', \ 'Arial \', \ 'Helvetica \', \ 'sans-serif \'; font-weight: bold; font-style: normal; margin-bottom: 5px; border-bottom: 3px solid #ddd; font-size: 18px; text-transform: uppercase; background: # 003a5b! important; border-color: #bbbbbb;margin-top: 20px;}. Interview with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross; 10 2020 Democrats Candidates to Debate in Miami Tonight; House Passes $4.5 Billion Bill for Humanitarian Aid at Border; Chipotle Unveils New Quarterly Bonus Program for Hourly Employees; Kim Kardashian Criticized for Making New Product Line "Kimono"; Groups Call on FTC to Take Action on YouTube Child Privacy ViolationsMORNINGS WITH MARIA MORNINGS WITH MARIA 7:00 AM ESTJune 26, 2019 WednesdayCopyright 2019 Fox Business Network LLC All Rights Reserved Section: NEWS; FinancialLength: 6947 wordsByline: Maria Bartiromo, Dagen Mcdowell, Cheryl CasoneGuests: Veronica Dagher, Wilbur Ross, Joel Marcus, Matt Schlapp, Ed Rendell, Kurt KnutssonBodyMARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Pretty important problem which is you have economics and national security all interwoven. This is not just a question about what's happening in the domestic economy. It's a question about these problems around the globe. Who is going to be in charge? I would rather it be us.BARTIROMO: Well, somebody says here the other day, the U.S. Has a duty to stop China. Don't miss it. We're going to talk a lot about what you just heard here with the President coming up this morning in about an hour.The President just tweeted on the border and the Democrats actually. And here's what the President just said. "Too bad the Dems in Congress won't do anything at all about border security. They want open borders which means crime but we are getting it done including building the wall. More people than ever before are coming because the U.S.A. economy is so good. The best in history." Writes the President this morning.Our top story this hour is "Gearing up for the G-20". The President is leaving today for the G-20 summit in Japan where he will meet face to face with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday among other leaders.Investors are watching this very high stakes meeting obviously The outcome could weigh heavily on markets and the global outlook as the world's two largest economies work to end an ongoing trade feud. The meeting comes amid signs of slowing Chinese consumer spending and a weakening Chinese economy.Joining me right now in a "Fox Business Exclusive" is Commerce Secretary, Wilbur Ross. Mr. Secretary -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining me.WILBUR ROSS, U.S. SECRETARY OF COMMERCE: Thank you for having me on -- Maria.BARTIROMO: So first let's talk China for a moment. Can the President accept a deal if the Chinese refuse to stop stealing intellectual property and forcing transfers of technology.ROSS: Well, As you know, there are several components that we've always had to the negotiations. The easy part is just solving to some degree the present deficit -- more soybeans, more LNG -- stuff like that.The second part, which is harder, is the structural reforms that you mentioned, -- property respect, not forced technology transfers, equal market access, things of that sort.And then the third bucket is the hardest one of all, which is enforcement and punishment in the event that there's a failure to live up to the structural reforms.BARTIROMO: Where would you say we are in terms of a deal? Are we closer than we ever have been or farther?ROSS: Well, you never have a deal on anything until you have a deal on everything.BARTIROMO: ok.ROSS: We got very, very far before the talks broke off but then there was retrograde motion by the Chinese. So hopefully they'll get back to where they were before they had a second thought and then we can go forward from there and close the remaining gaps.BARTIROMO: Mr. Secretary -- we're going to have an official from Huawei on the show tomorrow, actually. And I want to get your take on Huawei. You've got the Huawei black list, the U.S. ban taking a toll on certain American technology companies as well.Some now finding ways to resume business with Huawei, despite the ban and despite all the commentary about Huawei being a national security risk from this administration. The world's largest chip makers like Micron, Qualcomm, Intel restarting shipments to Huawei in ways that are still compliant with the Commerce Department restrictions. What's your reaction to that?ROSS: Well, there's always some marginal activity around the edges, relocating production from here to there, things of that sort. But the fundamental situation remains. We do have very severe national security concerns about Huawei. And we intend to use the proper measures to enforce the matters that have been put to rest.So we'll see how people are doing and we'll see what the outcome is. I don't think it's quite as simple as some of the stories.Huawei has been waging a huge PR campaign on the one hand saying oh, we are ok, everything is fine. And on the other hand saying there will be dire consequences.BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, what about FedEx? FedEx, of course, is suing the Commerce Department over the restrictions on Huawei following the recent shipping errors involving Huawei packages.We just heard from the CEO, Fred Smith, he was on Fox just the other day. I want to play this sound bite for you and get your reaction. Here's Fred Smith on "SPECIAL REPORT" last week.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)FRED SMITH, CEO, FEDEX: The increasing use of restrictions on exports and imports by the Commerce Department in various geopolitical and trade disputes creates just an impossible burden on FedEx and common carriers, because under the Department of commerce's regulations, we are expected to be policemen for these export and import controls.(END VIDEO CLIP)BARTIROMO: What about this lawsuit -- Secretary?ROSS: Yes. I have a great deal of respect for Fred, but he frankly is misinterpreting the regulations. What the regulations simply say is that neither FedEx nor any other common carrier can knowingly carry goods that are in violation of the rules -- knowingly. That means they have to know that they are in violation.We're not asking Fred or anyone else to be a policeman. We're just asking them not to conspire with people to avoid the things. So we look forward to dealing with that matter in the litigation. I think it's unfortunate that he has misinterpreted the rules. The courts will not misinterpret.BARTIROMO: Yes. But Secretary -- how are they supposed to know? I mean these are packages, right?ROSS: They don't have to know. They have to not know that it's a violation. The regulation says you cannot knowingly ship it. They do have mechanisms for trying to understand and they use -- remember, this is not new. There are over a hundred entities that are on the list.So it isn't as though this suddenly came out of the blue with Huawei. These processes have been going on for years. FedEx has pretty well complied with them over the years. I think this is a tempest in a tea pot.BARTIROMO: So when are you expecting this to go to the courts then? What's the timing on this?ROSS: Well, we already went to court the day that he appeared on you, on Fox, he filed it about the same time with the court.BARTIROMO: Ok.ROSS: And he gave me a wake-up call, a heads-up call just before he filed. And I tried to explain to him that he was misinterpreting the regulation but they went ahead and filed. So this will get itself dealt with.BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Secretary -- we just got news from Reuters that hackers working for China's Ministry of State Security broke into networks of eight of the world's biggest technology service providers. There was an effort to steal commercial secrets from their clients, according to sources familiar with these attacks.So here you have a meeting that's set, that the President is going to meet with President Xi Jinping at the G-20 on Saturday. And before this meeting you've got Chinese hackers directed by the Chinese government to get into these global telecom companies. Your reaction?ROSS: Well, I'm going to be at the G-20. In fact I'm leaving with everybody else in a couple hours to go there. It's not surprising timing. I think they're probably just trying to send us a message of their capabilities. But it certainly does not alleviate the very legitimate national security concerns that we have about Huawei and about other entities over there.BARTIROMO: What's the biggest national security risk -- Secretary? I understand that there are back doors. For example, just recently we heard from Vodaphone. The Vodaphone infrastructure includes Huawei infrastructure in Italy and an executive at Vodaphone noticed there was a back door in that infrastructure where all the data going through Vodaphone went back to the Chinese government.So can you in a practical way explain to our viewers what specifically is the national security risk around Huawei?ROSS: Well, the national security risk in concept is several things. One is invasion of phone conversations. Second would be disrupting them. Third would be taking other actions that paralyze whole systems. With the advent of 5G, which is really the big concern, everything is interrelated.Think about what the world would be like if you knocked out GPS, if you knocked out telecommunications all together.BARTIROMO: And the Chinese have the ability to do that, given that it's a Huawei, Chinese company. Real quick -- yes, go ahead, Secretary.ROSS: There's the danger. There's the danger of it. And because 5G is so software-driven, this artificial notion that you can segregate one part from another leaves us very, very skeptical.BARTIROMO: Secretary -- real quick, what would be a victory for the U.S. coming out of the G-20 meeting with President Xi Jinping?ROSS: Well, we're not looking for a victory. What we're looking for is a sensible deal that addresses the legitimate issues that we have. This is not a thing where one company is going to be pinned to the floor and knocked out. That's not the idea.The idea is, there are inappropriate activities underway by the Chinese. They must cease. If they do, and if we make some redressing of the trade imbalance, then that's a reasonable deal for both parties.So this is not a try to pin someone to the mat thing. This is to try to address some legitimate problems.BARTIROMO: And what if they don't agree to any of that?ROSS: Well, if they don't, they don't. The President has made it very clear that he's happy to go the alternate route if he has to. The alternate route of tariffs is not a bluff.BARTIROMO: Right. All right. Secretary -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks very much. Safe travels.ROSS: Thank you very much.BARTIROMO: Wilbur Ross.Stay with me for my exclusive interview with President Trump coming up at 8:00 a.m. Eastern this morning.BARTIROMO: Welcome back.President Trump is tweeting again this morning on the border. He says this. "Democrats want open borders which equals violent crime, drugs and human trafficking. They also want very high taxes like 90 percent Republicans want what's good for America, the exact opposite." Writes the President.This ahead of the first of the 2020 debates tonight. The Democratic primary debate tonight.Another tourist meanwhile falling ill in the Dominican Republic.Cheryl Casone with the details here. And Cheryl -- what? This is an incredible story.CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: It's a sad story -- Maria. 15-year-Candela Ciccone fell into a coma just before she was about to head home to Argentina. The doctors there believe that she has a life threatening diabetes condition even though her family says she has no history of diabetes. At least 12 Americans have died in the Dominican Republic under mysterious conditions.Well, Delta airlines is now allowing passengers that want to cancel or change their flight schedule to the Dominican Republic, they can do that now for free. Flight cancellations to the Caribbean nation have jumped 45 percent in the last few weeks. That's according to flight data company. Bookings have dropped, we should say, nearly 60 percent.All right. Audi is recalling more than 20,000 Q3 SUVs for turn signal issues. The affected vehicles the 2016 to 2018 model years. Audi says a software update will fix that problem.Well, the Justice Department has launched a criminal investigation into the chicken industry. Top poultry producers are being accused of colluding to keep prices high. The investigation includes Tyson Foods, Pilgrim's Pride, Sanderson Farms and Purdue Farms.All of these companies denying the accusations but shares of these companies actually fell pretty sharply when that news came out -- Maria.Those are your headlines.BARTIROMO: All right. Cheryl -- thank you.Coming up, tackling the drug crisis. My next guest discusses how his company's partnership with Google is tackling the opioid epidemic.Then Kardashian controversy. Kim Kardashian is facing backlash across the world today over the name of her new shapewear line, her critics, ahead.BARTIROMO: Welcome back.The opioid crisis, Alexandria Real Estate teaming up with Google to build a new way and place to fight the drug epidemic in America -- part of the campus is already open. The whole facility expected to be finished next year.Joining us right now is Alexandria Real Estate executive chairman and founder, Joel Marcus. Joel -- it's great to see you again.JOEL MARCUS, EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, ALEXANDRIA REAL ESTATE: Great pleasure -- Maria. Happy to be here.BARTIROMO: Why was this so important to you to be a part of this partnership?MARCUS: Well, as you know, we deal with campuses and building clusters to try to create innovative solutions to some of life's most challenging diseases.And over the past couple years we have studied and looked at the opioid crisis and it is probably the health crisis of our lifetime, much like AIDS was several decades ago. 115 people are dying every day, more than cumulatively have died in the Vietnam War. So we had to act.BARTIROMO: Tell us about the campus.MARCUS: So we studied with Google actually Verily, which is their subsidiary a couple of years ago and thought about trying to create a holistic campus where you could have from intake to detoxification, sober living, family reunification, job training and then ultimately job placement in a safe and secure environment.And we chose Dayton, Ohio because Dayton was in fact the patent capital of the world, the Wright Brothers were there. it had a long history of success but fell in with internationalization and the technology revolution, lost about two-thirds of its population and fell in to become really the center of the opioid crisis in America but they've actually done an amazing job over the last couple of years in reducing the deaths per capita.BARTIROMO: Wow.DAGHER: How many jobs in the community is this creating because it sounds like it's a very big campus.MARCUS: Well, it's about a 60,000 square foot campus that's in process. We have an outpatient piece now that we just opened about a week ago. Rob Portman was there -- Senator Portman. The goal though is really to create this safe environment and use it as a model for other communities.It's not so much about job placement. It's really about can we create a detoxification and a living situation that will help people permanently get off of the opioid situation. Because the amount of recidivism, the rate of recidivism after a 28-day treatment, you're put back on the street, is like 99 percent. It's just an awful statistic.SCHLAPP: What's interesting is you're intertwining this idea of drug addiction with economic opportunity, kind of a malaise. It takes both. Someone has to feel hope, right. Get off drugs, I feel like I can take care of my family obligations.MARCUS: Yes. Yes. I mean we always look at it as if you can revitalize a person, that's great philanthropy and good. And if you can help revitalize a community by putting people back into the workforce, that's got to be great business.So that's kind of how we thought about it.MCDOWELL: Joel -- what research did you rely on, basically related to preventing recidivism for opioid addictions that this is kind of environment that would deliver the best results.MARCUS: Yes. So we are focused on the infrastructure side and Verily obviously being an Alphabet or Google subsidiary, is really at the forefront of using data to try to create this.As you know, you could treat cancer patients all the same or you could treat them very specifically based on their own DNA and their own situation. So that's the meaning of targeted therapies. Everybody's tumor or blood cancer is different.Same thing in opioid crisis. There have been some famous -- there's a famous book and movie, "Beautiful Boy", which talked about the Chef (ph) family and the child was in -- started drugs at 11 years old. I think marijuana. And went into hard drugs. And only when they found that the underlying reason was for some of the addiction issues was bipolar disorder and depression were they able to treat that and then make success happen.MCDOWELL: I read that book.MARCUS: So it's a remarkable kind of situation. So we think a data-driven solution will be the key to success. Nobody knows yet because nobody's been successful really.BARTIROMO: Joel before you go, real quick on real estate, what are you seeing right now?MARCUS: Of course. Well, we've been fortunate. Our stock is up almost 25 percent since I saw you in early January.BARTIROMO: Every time I see you it's like it's up 60 percent since the last time I saw you. That's another 25 percent.MARCUS: So the demand still remains white hot in the great centers of innovation -- Cambridge, San Francisco, Seattle, San Diego and New York City and so forth. I think if you just think about 10,000 diseases, 500 addressable therapies, we're still in the early innings of trying to figure out disease and now we have the prospects of real cures.BARTIROMO: But the growth in tenants, technology, health sciences.MARCUS: And AG tech now.BARTIROMO: And AG tech.MARCUS: Yes. Our three fly wheels so-to-speak.BARTIROMO: Great to have you -- Joel.MARCUS: Great pleasure -- always. Thank you.BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. They want more government. They want a bigger social safety net when the government as exist today is doing a poor job running it.RENDELL: Well, you can debate that point. Medicare has about a two percent administrative overhead. Most private insurance companies have 10, 11 percent overhead. I think the president's idea of coming up with a solution in two weeks is unrealistic. The gridlock -- the gridlock --BARTIROMO: This is not a new problem in the last two weeks.RENDELL: The gridlock is embarrassing. But what's going on is worse. And I think the policies of the administration have perpetrated that.When President Obama left office there were less people trying to get into the United States than any time in recent history. Now, all of a sudden, it's soared because of the idea that we're going to close the borders and there's going to be no chance to get in.Look, the people who come here under false pretenses should be booted out and booted out as quickly as possible. Those things are all --BARTIROMO: Yes, it all requires money and they're running out of money this month.RENDELL: It does.BARTIROMO: All right, governor, great to have you here. The bid with the US, the common axis between Putin and Xi JinpingCE Noticias Financieras EnglishJune 6, 2019 ThursdayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 791 wordsBody In a meeting in which they showed good harmony, the presidents of Russia and China promised to strengthen their cooperation.  They agree to counter protectionism and Trump's unilateral approaches.  The presidents of Russia and China, Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping, promise to further strengthen the growing cooperation between the two countries, during a meeting held yesterday in the Kremlin, at times of tensions shared with the United States in trade and in almost all fronts of the world political arena.  After lavishing praise on each other and the ties of their countries, the leaders attacked the United States in a statement in which they expressed their intention to counter certain Washington trade policies and their rejection of the position of the government of President Donald Trump. regarding Venezuela and Iran.  "The parties intend to counteract the imposition of unfounded restrictions on access to markets for IT products with the excuse of guaranteeing national security, as well as the export of high technology products," the joint statement issued to the end of negotiations.  Thus the Russian and Chinese leaders reacted to the decision of the Donald Trump administration to veto the Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei, among other reasons, for accusations of industrial espionage and for being an "instrument" of the Chinese government.  For years, China and Russia increasingly question the global order led by the United States that followed World War II. "Protectionism and unilateral approaches are on the rise, and a policy of force and hegemony is increasingly in vogue," the Chinese president said, referring to tariffs by CNN.  On his eighth visit to Russia since he came to power, in 2012, Xi called Putin a "great friend" and said that both met more than 30 times in the past six years. "We decided that we will raise our bilateral relations to a higher level and that we will take our links to a new era," said Xi, sitting next to Putin in a Kremlin hall.  Against the USA  Russia's relations with the United States declined due to the Ukraine crisis, the war in Syria and accusations of Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election, while China is engaged in a trade war with the United States.  The Russian leader emphasized that Moscow and Beijing have the same vision on many global issues, and in particular, mentioned their shared opposition to the US withdrawal from the Intermediate Nuclear Forces Treaty (INF), a pact signed during the Cold War. considered a mainstay in the control of weapons.  Meanwhile, both leaders reiterated their rejection of a military intervention in Venezuela and called for an inclusive political dialogue between President Nicolás Maduro and the head of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó.  Mexico-USA  The United States has another open front. Yesterday, in Washington, negotiations between Vice President Michael Pence and Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard began to resolve a dispute originated when Trump ordered a 5 percent tariff on products from the Aztec country if it did not curb the flow of illegal immigrants.  The Mexican offensive, the largest delegation of officials in the era of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, seeks to achieve a commitment to avoid that tax before it goes into effect on Monday.  "Mexico wants to reach an agreement. They sent their best people to try, "said Trump, in a clear sign of predisposition todialogue.  Trade tension will reduce world GDP  The tariff war between the US and China can subtract half a percentage point from the global gross domestic product (GDP) in 2020, equivalent to the loss of some US $ 455,000 million, the Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Christine Lagarde, warned yesterday. recently announced tariffs between the United States and China could subtract around 0.3 percent of world GDP by 2020, "he said. Lagarde attributed" more than half "of this impact to the effects on business confidence and the financial market. He added that, taking into account also the tariffs implemented last year, world GDP in 2020 could be reduced by 0.5 percent. In this way, the official pointed out the priority to resolve current trade tensions while progressing in the modernization of the international trading system. This includes the formation of consensus among countries on how to strengthen the rules of the World Trade Organization ( WTO), particularly in the case of subsidies, intellectual property and trade in services. The IMF studies suggest that the liberalization of trade in services would release some US $ 350 billion in the economy in the long term. IMF revised its growth forecast for the world economy in 2019 two tenths downwards.       Load-Date: June 6, 2019End of Document

China Mobile Data Consumption Trends Markets 2019-2027 - Internet on Things and Advanced Technologies Gaining MomentumGlobeNewswireJune 12, 2019 Wednesday 4:40 AM PTCopyright 2019 GlobeNewswire, Inc. All Rights ReservedSection: RESEARCH ANALYSIS AND REPORTSLength: 821 wordsBodyDublin, June  12, 2019  (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The     "China Mobile Data Consumption Trends Market to 2027 - Regional Analysis and Forecasts By Subscriber Base and Technology"   report has been added to     ResearchAndMarkets.com's  offering.             The Internet subscriber base in China stood at 813.23 million, and it is expected to reach 1184.63 million in 2027 with a CAGR of 4.2% from 2019 to 2027.Young population drives the demand of internet applications is fueling the mobile data consumption market. In China, the share of young Internet users is huge in the overall internet user market, and it is a significant growth driver for internet services. In 2018, the total number of internet users in China reached 813.23 million, out of which the number of young Internet users under 20 was 22.4 %. Some of the major applications used by young internet users included online meal ordering, online travel bookings, live games, and live reality shows. E-commerce and online games applications have also grown significantly in the past year due to popularity among the young population. The driving forces behind the rapid growth of these segments among young users include continuous innovation, focus on mobility, internationalization, and competitiveness. This factor has created a potential market space for mobile data consumption market.The significant increase in the demand of internet on things and other advanced technologies is anticipated to fuel the mobile data consumption market growth. Smartphones are at the foundation of Internet of things concept, and their high penetration in China made them the driving force behind IoT adoption. As per the Made in China 2025 strategy of the Chinese government, the backing of advanced technologies such as 5G, artificial intelligence, and data analytics will further drive the development of these technologies, especially Industrial IoT.  For instance, in 2018, in 2018, mobile internet users reached 793.62 million, and it represented almost 97.59% of total internet subscribers in China. All these factors are enhancing the growth of mobile data consumption market.The increased demand for data consumption is driven by growing mobile applications such as instant messaging, online shopping, online streaming services, social networking, information services, financial services, sharing services and others. Also, affordable smartphones also laid the foundation for connected things/IoT and other enhanced personalized and smart applications which uses like AI and other new concepts. 5G is cited as a strategic priority in the government's 13th Five-year Plan. The government has also awarded grants to technology heavyweights ZTE and Huawei, which have received a reported US$72 Mn for technology development for 5G deployments. China's largest telecommunications providers intend to spend close to US$ 411 Bn for 5G rollout by 2030. IIoT will be 5G's most critical use case in support of China's Made in China 2025 initiative are proliferating the mobile data consumption market. Key Topics Covered:                   1. China rejects threats, tariffs as way to resolve trade warAssociated Press InternationalJune 20, 2019 Thursday 11:27 AM GMTCopyright 2019 Associated Press All Rights ReservedSection: BUSINESS NEWSLength: 625 wordsDateline: BEIJING BodyBEIJING (AP) - China warned Thursday that threats and tariffs will not resolve trade tensions between the two biggest economies and blasted Republican Sen. Marco Rubio for his criticism of technology giant Huawei over patents.Ministry spokesman Gao Feng said Thursday that its "core concern" over mutual respect has to be properly accommodated."If the US insists on taking unilateral trade measures against China, it will definitely bring serious impacts on the economy of itself and the welfare of its people," Gao said in a routine briefing.Trump and Xi are due to meet at a summit of the Group of 20 on June 28-29. It's unclear when the two countries' negotiating teams will resume detailed talks, which stalled in May when the U.S. accused China of reneging on earlier commitments.The talks are aimed at ending the dispute over trade and technology that has resulted in Trump imposing 25% tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese exports and considering expanding those tariffs to include another $300 billion of Chinese products.The Wall Street Journal reported last week that Huawei is asking U.S. phone carrier Verizon to pay licensing fees for more than 200 of its patents. While Huawei declined to comment on the matter, company spokesman Joe Kelly said it will hold a briefing later this month on being more aggressive about collecting intellectual property licensing fees.Rubio filed an amendment to the U.S. defense authorization bill this week that would prevent Huawei Technologies and other companies on security watch lists from pursuing damages in U.S. patent courts. That followed a move by Huawei to seek $1 billion in damages it says it is owed in unpaid patent licensing fees, reports said.A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman described Rubio's effort to block Huawei's lawsuit as "bizarre.""We know that someone in the U.S. leaves no stone unturned to smear and suppress other countries' enterprises, yet we did not expect that they would so blatantly manipulate the laws and rules," said the spokesman, Lu Kang."This not only damages the reputation and image of the U.S. but also harms its own companies in the long run."The U.S. has accused Chinese companies such as Huawei of committing forced technology transfers and stealing trade secrets. Last month, the U.S. placed Huawei on its "Entity List," which effectively bars American companies from selling components to Huawei without government approval.Washington claims Huawei poses a national security threat because it may be beholden to China's ruling Communist Party. But American officials have presented no evidence of any Huawei equipment serving as intentional conduits for espionage by Beijing. Huawei's placement on the Entity List is widely seen as intended to persuade resistant U.S. allies in Europe to exclude Huawei equipment from their next-generation wireless networks, known as 5G.Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei has denied that Huawei would share user data with the Chinese government if ordered to do so.On Monday during a panel discussion opened to the media he said there are no backdoors in Huawei's equipment that anyone could access, and that Huawei is willing to enter into a "no backdoor" agreement with any nation that wants one.Huawei brought a lawsuit in the U.S. this March challenging the constitutionality of a national security law which prevents the U.S. government and its contractors from using Huawei equipment. The complaint, filed in Plano, Texas, where Huawei's American operations are headquartered, alleges that the law singles out Huawei for punishment while denying the company due process.Ren said during the panel discussion that Huawei will not use its many patents as a "weapon," but did not rule out seeking royalties for usage.Load-Date: June 21, 2019End of Document

Eagle and Dragon II: Huawei and Battle for 5G MarketCE Noticias Financieras EnglishJune 22, 2019 SaturdayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 1048 wordsBody       The Chinese government will support Huawei – and the semiconductor industry – with all its power. (Image: Flickr)A white paper recently published by the Chinese government announces that it aspires to reach an agreement consistent with its "core interests" but will "never commit to matters of principle" as it is "not afraid" of a very costly trade war for both sides. It sounds like mere rhetoric, but it's not.Along side with the Chinese change of position in the May negotiations - explained in the last installment - Xi Jinping's publicized visit to a rare earth farm subtly warned Washington that Beijing would even bet on slowing chip production American, something that only the experts took note of. Unnecessary would be to warn that this would escalate censorship and repression by responding for the purposes of the trade war on its people. It is nothing for a political culture – intact in its authoritarianism – heir to Mao's crazed campaigns and genocidal famines. So the only thing at risk in China is Xi's credibility in terms of the overall strategy of his grand "china-made in China 2025" plan.The big "asymmetric" robberyThe problem for a reasonable agreement between China and the United States is the difference between what the parties consider reasonable:Beijing aims to maintain exchange rate manipulation, extreme protectionism of its domestic market, subsidies and privileges to mercantilist companies designated as "national champions" such as Huawei, which added to forced-to-cover transfer, industrial espionage on behalf of the State – together and for its protégés – and the brazen theft of technologies, in China, refer to a "asymmetrical" and "non-market" approach. This is key to Xi's grandiose China 2025 plan for China's new superpower.But this accelerated development strategy through the theft of technology, the conquest of developed markets for Chinese exports alongside the closure of the Chinese market to companies in those markets – except for limited quotas and with forced transfer and unlimited technology and management – it's what the Trump administration must neutralize one way or another. Washington can no longer turn a blind eye to Chinese mercantilism. It could afford to get China out of the misery of Maoist socialism by integrating it into the global market. Goals accomplished and far exceeded. It's already a competition for global hegemony. Washington risks too much without a bipartisan consensus on the issue. And the Chinese regime is trying to seize the window of opportunity of democratic weakness that only bipartisan consensuses neutralize.China's conservative wing clings to the "asymmetric strategy" because it would ensure they didn't give up an inch more in market reforms. The reformist wing also – although they would admit to reducing it partially and very slowly – because maintaining the abuse of concessions to underdeveloped economies in one that competes to control cutting-edge technology markets would ensure that developed countries outnumber in a few years. And the United States as the world's first economy. To submit to the same rules as the rest would be to give up what has worked for them. And they consider compatible with new reforms, limited and exclusively economic.huaweiFor Xi Jinping Huawei is the top "national champion" in China's global mercantilist expansion. Through Western human resources and technologies - a West that includes Japan andSouth – along with cheap labor and minimal environmental regulations in China – advantages in exchange for those that Western companies voluntarily and unintentionally delivered their technology and management to Chinese competitors, without gaining equivalent access to the Chinese market– the Chinese giant's products are as competitive – in quality, technological advancement and price – as to be a symbol of China's new superpower.That's why the regime is so committed to private Huawei as to arrest two Canadians on contrived espionage charges in retaliation for the arrest in Canada of a senior Huawei executive and daughter of the company's founder, in response to the request U.S. extradition on charges of national security-sensitive industrial espionage.The War for 5GThe Chinese government will support Huawei – and the semiconductor industry – with all its power. It trusts them to achieve a dominant global position in 5G technology. And controlling 5G would be to control the near technological future of the world. But Trump's executive order against Huawei seriously threatens Chinese telecoms giants. Western suppliers with immediately irreplaceable know-how are obliged to reject it. Google started. And British chip producer ARM Holdings followed, announcing that it will not license new products for Huawei. There will be others.With china's bid for a protracted trade war, Huawei would lose any chance of establishing itself in Western markets with 5 G technology. It would maintain expectations of expansion in much of Asia, Africa and Latin America. And the global 5G market would be split between the Western and the Chinese sphere. The battle between China and the West over politically sensitive technologies is served.The most unlikely scenario today is that Trump will surprise Osaka - or at another time in the near future - sneaking up on Beijing's aspirations. That would be something like Beijing's undetermined promises of approaching international rules - which Trump would present to his electorate as a great victory - in exchange for Washington's more or less covert and short-term promises of continuing to see elsewhere – that would strengthen Xi's position within the party. Even so would Huawei regain its previous access to Western markets to obtain key 5G components.Not only did Washington stand guard against China on sensitive technologies. Huawei will quickly lose involvement in Europe in smartphones and 5G. China will receive its own protectionist limitation medicine of its companies' participation in irreplaceable foreign markets. And the stakes to conquer underdeveloped markets from politically sensitive and radically anti-American bridgeheads will be revealed costly and fragile, something we will discuss in the third and final installment of this series about the Eagle and the Dragon.Load-Date: June 22, 2019End of Document

TWO MORE ETHNIC MONGOLIANS JAILED IN CHINA, WECHAT GROUPS DELETEDStates News ServiceApril 26, 2019 FridayCopyright 2019 States News ServiceLength: 766 wordsByline: States News ServiceDateline: WASHINGTON, DC BodyThe following information was released by Radio Free Asia:Chinese authorities in the northern region of Inner Mongolia have detained two more group chat moderators on the social media platform WeChat after they took part in demonstrations in support of herding communities, a New York-based rights group said on Friday.Ethnic Mongolian herders Bai Xiurong and Altanbagan, were detained by riot police at the scene of a demonstration outside government offices in Urad Middle Banner on April 22, the Southern Mongolian Human Rights and Information Center (SMHRIC) said in a statement on its website.More than 100 herders from the banner, a county-like division, had gathered in front of the local government building to demand a meeting with Bu Xiaolin, chairman of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, who was on a visit to the area, it said.Around a dozen people were detained, while Bai and Altanbagan were "thrown into SWAT vehicles" and each handed a 14-day administrative detention sentence, which is handed down by a police committee without the need for a trial."Bai Xiurong's sister was summoned yesterday ... She was forced to surrender Bai Xiurong's phone," SMHRIC quoted herder Tsetseg as saying in an audio message."The [police] accessed her phone and wiped out all the WeChat discussion groups she maintained," he said.Since Bai's arrest, her disabled elderly parents, who need constant care, have been left unattended, and her livestock have gone without food or water, SMHRIC said.Herders also traded information about the detentions on WeChat, in spite of the group chat shutdowns, it said."Some were released around midnight and the early morning of April 23 while [the rest of us] herders staged a sit-in outside the government building, demanding the immediate release of all arrested herders," an unidentified local herder said via the social media platform.Footage of the protest sent to SMHRIC showed hundreds of police arriving at the scene.One protester says in the video: "We are treated like animals. They rounded up us like fencing up livestock," he said. "Whoever comes to the government to express his or her opinion is arrested like this."Three writers detainedThe detentions come after authorities in the region detained three ethnic Mongolian writers for speaking out for their ethnic group in the face of action by Chinese government officials and companies.Tsogjil, 40, who hosted a number of discussion groups on the social media platform WeChat, was detained on April 16 in the regional capital Hohhot. He had been preparing to file an official complaint with the regional government on behalf of ethnic Mongolian herders in Heshigten Banner.O. Sechenbaatar, 68, was detained along with a herder named Baldan at a protest near Lake Dalainuur in the region's Heshigten Banner earlier this month. He has been placed under criminal detention on suspicion of "obstructing officials in the course of their duty," it said.Sechenbaatar had also hosted a number of WeChat groups to provide local Mongolian herders with a venue to discuss the pressing issues in their communities, including mining, environmental destruction, pollution, and herders' protests, SMHRIC said.Tsogjil had used one of his WeChat groups to rally herding communities to a protest outside the Heshigten Banner government, calling for Sechenbaatar's release.Both writers are being held at the Heshigten Banner Detention Center.Earlier this month, ethnic Mongolian author Lhamjab A. Borjigin, 75, stood trial on charges of "separatism" and "sabotaging national unity" at the Shiliinhot Municipal People's Court.For his book China's Cultural Revolution, published in 2006, Lhamjab gathered oral testimonies of survivors of violence against ethnic Mongolians during the Cultural Revolution, a task that took him 20 years.The book accuses the ruling Chinese Communist Party of state-sponsored genocide in the region, detailing torture techniques and detentions in a brutal campaign that claimed the lives of at least 27,900 people and imprisoned and tortured 346,000.Ethnic Mongolians, who make up almost 20 percent of Inner Mongolia's population of 23 million, increasingly complain of widespread environmental destruction and unfair development policies in the region.Clashes between the authorities or Chinese state-backed mining or forestry companies and herding communities are common in the region, which borders the independent country of Mongolia.But those who complain about the loss of their grazing lands are frequently targeted for harassment, beatings, and detention by the authorities.Load-Date: April 27, 2019End of Document

Alice Lin, Daughter of U.S. Pastor Held by Chinese Govt, to Speak out Publicly for First Time on Washington Watch with Tony PerkinsPR NewswireApril 8, 2019 Monday 5:16 PM ESTCopyright 2019 PR Newswire Association LLC All Rights ReservedLength: 168 wordsDateline: WASHINGTON, April 8, 2019 BodyPR NewswireAlice Lin, the daughter of a U.S. pastor held hostage by the Chinese government for more than a decade, will give her first media interview on today's edition of Washington Watch with Tony Perkins. Last December, China launched a crackdown on Christian church members that appears to have impacted those held in prison -- including Pastor David Lin.  The worsening situation has prompted the Lin family to call on the U.S. and Chinese governments to intervene to help bring the pastor back to the United States.Who:  Alice Lin, daughter of U.S. Pastor David LinWhat:   Radio interview on Washington Watch with Tony PerkinsWhen:  5:32 PM Eastern timeWhere:  Listen online attonyperkins.comGo tohttp://www.freepastorlin.com for more information. View original content to download multimedia:http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/alice-lin-daughter-of-us-pastor-held-by-chinese-govt-to-speak-out-publicly-for-first-time-on-washington-watch-with-tony-perkins-300826497.htmlSOURCE Family Research CouncilCONTACT: J.P. China's premier meets New Zealand's leader amid 5G disputeAssociated Press InternationalApril 1, 2019 Monday 9:40 AM GMTCopyright 2019 Associated Press All Rights ReservedSection: BUSINESS NEWSLength: 661 wordsByline: By CHRISTOPHER BODEEN, Associated PressDateline: BEIJING BodyBEIJING (AP) - Chinese Premier Li Keqiang urged New Zealand to provide a "fair, transparent, convenient" investment environment in a meeting Monday with the country's prime minister, Jacinda Ardern, that comes amid a dispute over use of Chinese telecoms equipment.Relations between the two countries have been strained since New Zealand in November stopped mobile phone company Spark from using Huawei gear in its planned 5G upgrade because of security concerns.In opening remarks at their meeting Monday in Beijing, Li did not mention Huawei directly but said China wanted improved relations that would serve the best interests of businesses on both sides."China ... is willing to, on the basis of mutual respect and equal treatment, elevate mutual political trust with New Zealand, expand practical cooperation and increase personal exchanges," Li told Ardern at the Great Hall of the People, the seat of the legislature in central Beijing, following a formal welcoming ceremony."And we hope that ... when each side's businesses invest in each other's businesses, they can enjoy a fair, transparent, convenient environment," Li said.Ardern did not address investment issues in her opening remarks, but thanked Li for expressing China's condolences over the deadly shootings at mosques in the city of Christchurch. Her visit was cut back to one day following the March 15 shootings that killed 50 people.Ardern said she still wanted to "visit Beijing at this time to underline the importance that we place on our relationship with China. It is one of our most important and far reaching relationships, a point I've made in my public speeches over the past year."Following the meeting, the two leaders oversaw the signing of agreements on avoiding double taxation, agriculture, financial dialogue and science and research.Ardern met later in the day with Chinese president and head of the ruling Communist Party Xi Jinping, who also expressed his condolences and said both countries must "adhere to mutual trust, the principle of mutual benefit and continue to develop the spirit of striving to be first.""We will continue to enrich the meaning of China-New Zealand comprehensive strategic partnerships, push forward the relationship between the two countries even further, and better serve the people of China and New Zealand," Xi said.The cordial tone comes after months of tensions between the sides, during which official visits and exchanges were delayed or postponed.The determination by New Zealand's spy agency that Huawei's equipment posed a "significant network security risk" sparked deep indignation in China, where the company is considered a national champion.New Zealand has been caught in the fray as the U.S. cautions allies against partnering with Huawei over national security concerns. The country is part of the "Five Eyes" security alliance along with the U.S., Britain, Canada and Australia.The agency's move brought condemnations in China's state media and indications of economic retaliation. China is a key customer for its dairy and other agricultural products. New Zealand's government says two-way trade between the sides more than tripled in the 10 years since a free trade agreement between the sides came into force in 2008.China is New Zealand's biggest trading partner, with $19 billion in commerce between them last year, as well as a key source of tourists and foreign students.Ardern said last month that no final decision has been made on whether Huawei equipment can be used in the country's slated 5G network.Human Rights Watch had called on Ardern to raise concerns about reported Chinese government abuses of Muslims during her visit, although it wasn't clear if she planned to do so. The group said Ardern "spoke forcefully in defense of Muslims' rights" after the Christchurch attacks and should do so again in Beijing.___This story has been corrected to show that the China-New Zealand free trade agreement started in 2008.Load-Date: April 2, 2019End of Document

Analysts: China Isn't Targeting Apple In Trade WarBenzinga.comMay 30, 2019 Thursday 3:05 PM GMTCopyright 2019 Accretive Capital LLC d/b/a Benzinga All Rights ReservedLength: 438 wordsByline: Wayne DugganBodyApple, Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL) has taken a beating in the month of May on concerns a breakdown in U.S. trade relations with China could leave Apple exposed to a potential boycott in China. Two analyst said Thursday Apple s seems to have steered clear of trade war disruption up to this point, but it's still caught in the middle of a high-risk situation.Bank of America analyst Wamsi Mohan reiterated his Buy rating and $230 price target for Apple.Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty reiterated her Overweight rating, but lowered her price target from $240 to $231.iPhone Usage SteadyThe U.S. Commerce department blacklisted Huawei this month, a move that caused plenty of Apple investors to worry that China could do the same for Apple in retaliation. Mohan said if China targets Apple, it could be inflicting more harm on itself than America. Bank of America estimates more than 2 million Chinese workers are employed in the Apple supply chain, making it difficult target for the Chinese government.In addition, Mohan said a survey of more than 194,000 consumers around the globe indicates there has been no decline in intent to buy iPhone s. The number of respondents indicating they intend their next smartphone purchase to be an iPhone has remained steady at around 30 percent through May. In China specifically, that percentage dipped from 32 percent in March to 26 percent in April, but has rebounded to 29 percent in May.Mohan said App Store sales in China are actually on the rise.Informal Ban, PerhapsHuberty said it s unclear whether or not Apple can get its devices exempt from the latest round of U.S. tariffs. However, she said it s unlikely China will target iPhones given they are currently produced inside China. More likely in our view is that the government could place an informal ban on purchasing certain products as it has done in the past for parts of the market (such as for government officials several years ago), which could have a negative impact on iPhone demand,  Huberty wrote in a note.She said even if the government doesn t formally ban iPhones, Chinese consumers may also step in and boycott on their own.Price ActionApple's stock traded marginally higher at $177.92 per share on Thursday.Related Links:Citi Cuts Apple Price Target, iPhone Estimates On China ConcernsAnalyst: Huawei Blacklist Is $400M Risk For GoogleLatest Ratings for AAPLDateFirmActionFromToMay 2019MaintainsOverweightMay 2019MaintainsOverweightMay 2019MaintainsBuyView More Analyst Ratings for AAPL           View the Latest Analyst Ratings© 2019 Benzinga.com. Benzinga does not provide investment advice. All rights reserved.Load-Date: May 31, 2019End of Document

Beijing confirms arrest of Chinese citizen accused of spying on Trump tourist complexCE Noticias Financieras EnglishApril 4, 2019 ThursdayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 278 wordsBody The Chinese government today confirmed the arrest of "a Chinese citizen" who tried to enter last weekend with a USB stick that contained a malicious program in the tourist complex of US President Donald Trump in Palm Beach (Florida).  "On April 3, the Chinese Consul General in Houston received a notification from the United States that a Chinese citizen had been arrested. The consul contacted the person in question and offered him consular assistance, "Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang said today.  In this way, China recognizes that it has contacted this person, that the US identifies as Yujing Zhang, a woman who managed to pass a first inspection point in the Trump club during a visit from Trump to Palm Beach.Zhang, who faces up to five years in prison and $ 350,000 in fines, managed to enter the compound with two Chinese passports, four cell phones, a hard drive, a laptop and the device with the malicious program , according to the lawsuit.  Meanwhile, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has begun an investigation to determine if it is an espionage activity.  Federal agents told local media that Zhang made false statements and entered a building or restricted land.  FBI investigators are now trying to find out who Zhang is, if she is involved in a possible Chinese intelligence mission and if there are links to the social events of Cindy Yang - director of a consulting firm that promises Chinese entrepreneurs contacts with the environment.
