STOLEN SECRETS SAVEDStates News ServiceJune 6, 2019 ThursdayCopyright 2019 States News ServiceLength: 546 wordsByline: States News ServiceDateline: WASHINGTON, DC BodyThe following information was released by the FBI:FBI Investigators Thwarted Transfer of Trade Secrets to ChinaThe laptop, thumb drives, cell phones, and other items confiscated from Wengfeng Lu during his 2012 arrest as he tried to board a plane to China with stolen trade secrets.Wenfeng Lu was seemingly living the American dreama comfortable life in Irvine, California, with his family and a career in medical device research and development.Yet Lu's secret goal was to use trade secrets stolen from his employer to strike it rich in his native China. However, thanks to an FBI investigation, his plan was thwarted, and Lu is now serving a 27-month prison sentence.Lu worked for several different U.S. companies, all of which developed high-tech medical equipment, such as clot retrieval tools and balloon-guide catheters. In each job, Lu signed a non-disclosure agreement for his research and development work.Despite signing the confidentiality agreement, Lu routinely did data dumps from his various medical research employers for about three years until his arrest in 2012. Lu transferred all of the data he could get his hands on to a personal laptop. Many of the hundreds of documents Lu stole had nothing to do with his own research; he took as much information as he could access, including proprietary information.He had access to so many files, not just for his own projects, and he downloaded files for a variety of different projects and took them home and to China, said Special Agent Gina Kwon, who investigated this case out of the FBI's Los Angeles Field Office.One of Lu's former employers noticed the unusual activity on their systems and reported the results of their internal investigation to the FBI. Investigators quickly proceeded to build their case and arrested Lu, just before he boarded a plane to China with the files.These cases are important for the economic prosperity of our country.Gina Kwon, special agent, FBI Los AngelesThe investigative team learned that Lu had planned to create and run his own medical device manufacturing company in China using the stolen technology and Chinese government funding. He had even applied for Chinese patents using technology stolen from the American companies. (China's government creates policies that disadvantage American businesses, and hacking against American companies and interests is a common tactic.)Lu wanted his own business, and he thought there was a great market in China for this technology, Kwon said.Kwon said the American company's quick response to the unusual activity on their systems was key to the successful investigation. That's why the FBI works closely with private sector companies to build relationships and promote information sharing. Kwon encouraged the victim companies in this caseand all companies who have trade secretsto compartmentalize access to files so each employee only has access to what is needed for his or her job.These cases are important for the economic prosperity of our country, Kwon said. China and others are doing what they can to cut corners by stealing technology from American companies. It's detrimental to U.S companies because they've spent years and money to develop the technology, and it undercuts their ability to sell it competitively.Load-Date: June 6, 2019End of Document

Chinese regulators slap Ford's joint venture with $23.6 million fineCNN WireJune 5, 2019 Wednesday 8:42 AM GMTCopyright 2019 Cable News Network All Rights ReservedLength: 394 wordsByline: By Sherisse Pham, CNN BusinessDateline: HONG KONG (CNN Business) BodyHONG KONG (CNN Business) --  Chinese regulators have fined Ford's main joint venture in the country for violating antitrust laws. China's State Administration for Market Regulation slapped Changan Ford with a 162.8 million yuan ($23.6 million) fine for setting minimum resale prices on its cars in the city of Chongqing, according to a statement posted on the regulator's website on Wednesday. The fine amounts to 4% of the company's sales in Chongqing last year. Ford owns 50% of the joint venture, with the rest controlled by its local partner, state-owned carmaker Changan Automobile. Changan Ford's actions deprived downstream dealers of pricing autonomy, restricted competition and damaged the legitimate interests of consumers, the regulator said. Ford said it "respects" the market regulator's decision. "Changan Ford has taken corrective action in its regional sales management together with its dealers," a Ford spokesperson said in a statement. "As an ethical company, Ford is committed to complying with local laws and regulations wherever we do business," the spokesperson added. The move on a storied American carmaker comes at a tense time in US-China relations. The escalating trade war between the two countries and tit-for-tat punitive actions have sent shivers through the global economy and rattled investors. After Washington barred US companies from supplying critical software and components to Chinese tech giant Huawei, Beijing announced it was establishing its own blacklist for foreign companies. Earlier this week the Chinese government said it's investigating FedEx after Huawei said the delivery company diverted to the United States two packages intended for the company's offices in China.The penalty also comes as Ford is looking to make up lost ground in China. The carmaker announced in April that it plans to launch more than 30 new Ford and Lincoln vehicles in China over the next three years as it tries to reverse a decline in sales in the world's biggest auto market.China is Ford's second biggest market after the United States. But like other carmakers it is feeling the effects of China's slumping auto industry --- Ford's sales in the country plunged by nearly 40% in 2018 compared to the previous year.Serenitie Wang contributed to this report.TM & © 2019 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. All rights reserved.NotesUpdated at 4.41 a.m. ET: Adds detail about Ford joint venture in China. Load-Date: June 6, 2019End of Document

Facebook is tightening its live streaming rules. The social media giant announcing a one strike policy voving to temporarily restrict users who break company guidelines. This move is in response to the live streaming of the Christ Church massacre in New Zealand. Joining me right now is Elevation Partners cofounder, managing director, and author of Zucked: Waking up to the Facebook Catastrophe, Roger McNamee. A long time and early investor in Facebook who's become over the last two years, you know, two years much more active and cautious on this company. Great to see you, Roger.ROGER MCNAMEE, FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS: Maria, it's always great to see you.BARTIROMO: Thank so much for joining us. So what about this tightening of the rules at Facebook? Is this enough -- does this address your concerns?MCNAMEE: It does not. What I love and I really -- I really support Mark in his engagement in the issues. He really does understand there is no place to hide any longer. But they are doing classic public relations of conceding things that don't matter, that wouldn't actually change the outcome to try to protect the business model that's really what is at the heart of the problem.BARTIROMO: But what are they going to do? I mean, how -- that is the business model, right?MCINTYRE: I mean, the business model is dependent on getting people's engagement and by promoting the stuff people engage with, you're naturally going to be promoting hate speech, you're going to promote disinformation, you're going to promote conspiracy theories. And they make a lot of money because of promoting that stuff. So what they want to do is find a way to make the P.R. problem go away without actually having to get rid of the content that causes the problem in the first place.And in this case, you know, the notion that people are going to be able to police this get it done before any harm is done is ridiculous. You have to find a way to take away the incentive. It's all about, you know, status is what people are looking for. And so these extremists, these terrorists are looking to use Facebook to get status by promoting their act of terror online. So it's the fact that you can do it that is the problem.BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, the bigger issue I guess is this company has an enormous amount of power, more so within a lot of people understood, same with Google. This is why Chris Hughes, one of the founders of the company writes a piece in the New York Times last week, they got a lot of play, a lot of conversation about it that it's time to break up Facebook.MCINTYRE: Well, Chris makes an absolutely essential point about the power situation because Facebook and Google are not elected and yet they have more impact on our democracy than anything has ever had in the past. They have more impact on our public health, on our privacy and frankly on the economy. And the core issue here is what are the best ways to handle that? And I want to use antitrust to in order to create opportunity for competitive models to happen.I want to get back to entrepreneurship. You know, you and I have known each other a longtime when Silicon Valley was about small companions doing amazing new things. And now we're totally dependent on these monopolists but the other thing you have to do is go after that business model. We have to get these companies out of the world. They're basically using surveillance and purchasing data and trading data to get to know everything about us.They make these digital voodoo dolls of each and every one of us. We have no idea how much data they have, we have no idea what they're doing with it and we are so dependent on these products without realizing that they're manipulating our behavior. And that has to stop, it's just -- it's not American, it's -- that's kind of the Chinese way of doing things and I just don't want to see us going down that path.BARTIROMO: What have you heard back, you know, in response to criticism from the company? You wrote a whole book about it, Zucked. It's been getting incredible play since you published it.MCNAMEE: I give Mark a lot of credit because he is engaging in the conversation but he's got really good P.R. handlers who are saying to him, Mark, make this little concession here, it will go away. Make that little concession there, it will go away. And fortunately, the flow of news have been so intense that people have not been satisfied with the little moves that they've made. But unlike Google at least they're in the conversation.BARTIROMO: Yes. That's true.MCNAMEE: Google trying to pretend, hey, none of this has anything to do with us.BARTIROMO: You're absolutely right.MCNAMEE: Which is complete nonsense.BARTIROMO: Yes.MCNAMEE: And so I look at this as, you know, in their shoes, probably a lot of CEOs would handle the same way they're doing it. But I want them to sit there and realize, this succeeded beyond their wildest dreams. This is an opportunity for Mark to be hero of his own story.BARTIROMO: Yes. And just to be clear, even though you have been sort of cautious and negative and speaking out about the issues around the company, you really haven't sold much stock. I mean --(CROSSTALK)MCNAMEE: Yes. The critical thing -- I continue to have -- it's continuously by far my largest position. And the key thing is, I don't think this is about the people. I am not critical of Mark, I'm not critical of Sheryl or of Larry, Sergey --BARTIROMO: About the business model.MCNAMEE: It's about the business model, it's about the culture and it's about this notion that somehow they're entitled to essentially convert everybody's human experience into data and then use that to manage our lives because we all go to them for information. What we don't realize is they're using their control of the menu to control the choices available to us and that's not a good thing.BARTIROMO: We talk a lot about China and how China is, you know, tracking its citizens, facial technology, they've got, you know, all this data on everybody. The closest thing to China in this country --MCNAMEE: Is Google and then Facebook. And my point is they say you can't regulate us because we have to compete with China. I go, why do we want to compete with China in behavioral manipulation? We don't. We want to apply A.I. and all this technology to all the things you can do to make humanity better off.BARTIROMO: What's the fear around A.I.?MCNAMEE: Well, the legitimate fears are coming in two different areas. One is that, you train Artificial Intelligence with data from the real world. So if you're not really careful, you reproduce all the problems of the real world without a human being to go and complain to. So, if you sit there and think about this we've had huge issues in corporations for recruiting with resume applications that retain the real world biases against women, against older people.BARTIROMO: -- bias right in there.MCNAMEE: Exactly. And my point is you have to really careful and it's doable. The other problem with A.I. is that you -- they're almost inscrutable, it's almost impossible to tell until you do something when you start at the beginning what's going to coming out at the end and so, you sit there and say, well, we can get an A.I. to drive a car. And I'm sitting there and going, hang on.BARTIROMO: Hang on.MCNAMEE: Driving cars with humans on the road is really complicated. And we cannot count on these things to get it right without an awful lot of tests.BARTIROMO: I don't think we're going to see a fully autonomous driverless car on road for a decade. I know what Elon Musk is saying. I'm not buying it. I'm not.MCNAMEE: I hope we don't.BARTIROMO: Yes.MCNAMEE: I mean, if we do it will be very, very dangerous.BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about Microsoft. The company is sounding the alarms this morning, warning of a monster computer bug that could be used as cyberweapon. What do you know about this and how do these problems keep popping up?MCNAMEE: Well, the issue you have with Microsoft and frankly with all the gigantic web platforms is they are so huge and they have so much out there that inevitably things fall through the cracks. Microsoft has been patching and upgrading Windows forever and this bug is about older versions of Windows. And do you know the sad part? That means government agencies and corporations that don't upgrade regularly are the ones who are going to be victimized by this, what's in the worst possible places.And now that everybody knows the bug is there, there is a real risk with super important that anyone who has those old versions of Windows, upgrade immediately. Put the patch in place and, you know, the thing with computer technology is it is far more risky than we've allowed for and we have to budget both the expense and the energy to keep these things current and protected.BARTIROMO: We've reported on this a lot because Steve Ballmer came on the show and told me and confirmed to me that 90 percent of the companies in China use the Microsoft operating system, one percent pay for it.MCNAMEE: Exactly.BARTIROMO: It's a -- it's a -- it's a loss of $10 billion a year for Microsoft. When it comes to China I.P. theft, you know, this is the big issue in terms of --MCNAMEE: It is a huge issue.BARTIROMO: The President is pushing back using, you know, I just want to point out that April retail sales, worse than expected. It was down two- tenths of a percent. We were expecting retail sales to be up two-tenths of a percent. So this China fight is one thing that people are talking about whether or not it's going to impact the economy, we don't know. But April retail sales down two-tenths of a percent for the month. That is a worse- than expected number and markets are down this morning. They were already down going into it, but the big issue here, the President using tariffs, the real elephant in the room, as you know, is the I.P. theft, the forced transfer of technology.MCNAMEE: Oh, and in my mind, it's not just I.P. theft. The forward looking risk is the notion that they bring their behavioral manipulation, their what they call the social credit application into other countries around the world, including the United States and I don't think we want to allow that. So, I believe that having a better reciprocal relationship with China requires holding to a much higher standard on intellectual property.BARTIROMO: Hmm.MCNAMEE: And realistically, we have built our economy around buying stuff from China. We need to get back to making a lot more stuff here. We need to get back to investing more, consuming less.BARTIROMO: Yes.MCNAMEE: I don't know that the country is emotionally prepared to consume less, but if you're worried about China, that's got to be a big part of the answer.BARTIROMO: Yes.MCNAMEE: And -- because right now, you go into a retail store, what is it, like in a Walmart, like 90 percent of what's there is made in China?BARTIROMO: Do you think China's economy gets impacted more than the U.S. economy from this fight?MCNAMEE: It does, but we both get hurt.BARTIROMO: Yes.MCNAMEE: And it's -- and it's needless.BARTIROMO: Again, the retail sales are down, two-tenths of a percent versus an estimate of up two-tenths of a percent. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is, Wednesday, May 15th. Your top stories right now 8:35 a.m. on the East Coast. Breaking news this morning, retail sales for the month of April down two-tenths of one percent. The estimate was for a gain of two-tenths of a percent. A disappointing number here. S&P 500 down 16-1/2, NASDAQ down 45 points, two-thirds of one percent.Joining us right now is MacroMavens President, Stephanie Pomboy with reaction. Good to see you, Stephanie.STEPHANIE POMBOY, PRESIDENT, MACROMAVENS: Good morning. Good to see you.BARTIROMO: Not a good month of April.POMBOY: No, I would say so. Actually, I thought if anything, the number would surprise on the upside. I mean we had a strong employment report in April. We had the market returning to record highs, seasonally, the bar for April is much lower in terms of the adjustment hurdle that the data has --BARTIROMO: What do you happened here?POMBOY: That's wonky a thing, so --BARTIROMO: What do you think happened here?POMBOY: Well, I think the fact that it disappointed really speaks to the longer-term underlying weakness that we're seeing, you know, as we've talked about many times before, the fed, when it started raising rates in December 2015, that had an immediate impact on households. We didn't notice it in the financial community because corporate borrowing costs continue to move lower. Government, you know, treasury yields continue to move lower, even in the face of a fed tightening. But it was a slow and steady drain on households who saw their interest expense move up, and it hasn't been fully offset, I guess, by the increase in wage inflation.So, you're still seeing some pressure on households and that's reflected in, like, delinquency rates, you know, the credit card delinquency rates continue to move higher along with autos and student loans. So, there's been distress building there which is why I felt like we'd have the sort of short-term bounce in the economy, but longer term, those factors would begin to weigh on. What I think is really important about this disappointing number is how it dovetails with the whole tariff issue now because --BARTIROMO: Yes, this was before the tariffs went into effect.POMBOY: Exactly, and I guess, you know, the sort of glib reaction to the tariff thing is, oh, well, consumers are have going to pay those increased prices. I'm not so sure. You look at these numbers, what company is going to be able to pass along higher prices to their consumers?DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And I think the vast majority, and correct me if I'm wrong, of this $200 billion tranche where we now have officially 25 percent tariffs on those goods, I think a large percentage, if not the majority, is intermediate goods. So, it's goods used in manufacturing. So what do they do? They don't pass on the higher costs, they cut jobs.POMBOY: Yes. Well, this is an issue that's not new. I mean if you look at the interplay between the CPI, which is the Consumer Price Index, and the PPI, which gets into the input cost, we have had issue with input cost going up faster than consumer prices for a long time. In fact, 20 over the last 24 months, the PPI has been faster than the CPI, which implies some real margin pressure for companies and obviously, these retail sales number this morning suggests that's not going to disappear, it might actually be intensifying and then you layer on top the tariffs.ANTHONY SCARAMUCCI, FORMER WHITE HOUSE COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR: Stephanie, what do you think the number of small businesses in the United States that are affected by the tariffs and have to pay extra? I mean you'll give you an example, my cousin, Auggie is an auto glass installer, he's getting annihilated by the tariffs. There's only certain auto glass that can be purchased from China and he's paying and he cannot pass it on to the end consumers. So, how many of those are out there, you think?POMBOY: Well, I guess it -- it's hard to quantify. I mean it really depends on specific industries, but clearly, that's going to be a major issue in terms of the employment side. You know, and you did see --SCARAMUCCI: To put pressure on jobs because the small businesses really do create the jobs.POMBOY: Absolutely, and we did see though yesterday, the NFIB, small business array, which was better for the month. Now, again, that's before this whole tariff thing went into effect, but I'm surprised given what you're talking about that they haven't been a little bit more pressured by all the trade talk up until now.BARTIROMO: What's your estimate in terms of how much growth the tariff situation takes out of annual economic growth?POMBOY: well, I mean I guess there is the one percent of GDP is exports to China, so that's a, you know, in the scheme of things, it seems fairly minor, but obviously, there are ripple effects that are much broader than that. And I guess what I really wrestle with is more the psychological effect here of, you know, if you're a businessman, and you see this trade war going on and tariffs coming on, how do you move forward? You know, do you adjust your capex plans? So, you know, do you decide to put a hold on hiring, so it can have a much more material effect than just --BARTIROMO: You just have an estimate. OK. Than a fractional estimate.MCDOWELL: Can I -- can I ask you really quickly? Alice Rivlin passed away. DO IT BETTER/The trade War and MexicoCE Noticias Financieras EnglishJune 14, 2019 FridayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 502 wordsBody       20 years ago Mexico was not easy: China was about to enter the World Trade Organization and this, coupled with its cheap labor, led many companies, some of which were located in Mexico, to move their operations there. The story is different today. The trade war between China and the United States has opened up important opportunities for Mexico. Since last year, we are already the main trading partner of the United States, a place that formerly occupied China. Compared to us imports of 2017 with those of 2018 it is easy to see how, in areas where the Asian giant fell Mexico grew. Leather products, fertilizers, textiles, automobiles, metal and aluminum products are just examples of this phenomenon. The rise in tariffs occurs in a context where wages in China are no longer low, and the growing mistrust with the US has aggravated the risk of intellectual property in producing there. All this re-positioned Mexico as an attractive option. What companies are moving to Mexico? A little bit of everything. Fuling Global, for example, is a company that makes paper and straw rates for restaurants in the United States and, after the paper tariff, changed its operations from the city of Wenling, China, to Monterrey, also saving the cost of transportation. The same story has been repeated with flagship companies like Hasbro, which manufactures toys, or GoPro, which manufactures cameras and high-resolution video. In this trade war, Mexico also becomes an attractive destination for Chinese investment that will seek to enter key sectors such as telecommunications or infrastructure, and countries that are strategically located or allied to their enemy. The commercial war on issues like technology is at a delicate time. Just look at what just happened with Huawei, a company that, being considered an arm of the Chinese government, will not sell you software, hardware or licenses from key vendors like Google, Intel and Qualcomm. In the face of these conflicts, Mexico will have to understand what its main interests are while learning to negotiate. The conflict between these two countries will not soon be over, so if Mexico manages to improve some key variables and give certainty and confidence, it can take better advantage of the opportunity. This trade war will change the map of the productive chains of many industries. Taking advantage of this will also require Mexican leaders with vision. In the political and diplomatic sphere to this administration it will take time to learn the art of dealing with Trump, whose main goal is the re-election, and with an authoritarian government like the Chinese, who does not account for anyone. There are no recipes, everything will be trial and error. But the only truth is that, despite the diplomatic difficulties of the last few weeks, the situation is still smiling on us. In the medium term, in the trade war between the United States and China, everyone loses, except perhaps Mexico... If you play it right.  veronicaebaz@gmail.com       Load-Date: June 14, 2019End of Document

Why tariff war threatens Beijing's global economic ambitionsAssociated Press InternationalMay 13, 2019 Monday 3:41 AM GMTCopyright 2019 Associated Press All Rights ReservedSection: INTERNATIONAL NEWSLength: 1036 wordsByline: By JOE McDONALD, AP Business WriterDateline: BEIJING BodyBEIJING (AP) - China's intensified tariff war with the Trump administration is threatening Beijing's ambition to transform itself into the dominant player in global technology.The United States is a vital customer and source of technology for Chinese makers of electronics, medical equipment and other high-tech exports - industries that the ruling Communist Party sees as the heart of its economic future.Yet to the Trump administration, they're a threat to America's industrial leadership.Beijing managed to keep Chinese economic growth steady in the most recent quarter despite a drop in exports to the United States. It did so by boosting government spending and bank lending. But China's technology exporters suffered huge sales drops of up to 40 percent, which ate into profits that pay for technology research.The tariff war is compounding the pain felt by many Chinese companies. They are already enduring stiffened resistance in the United States and Europe to Chinese acquisitions of technology through joint ventures with foreign companies or, with financing by state-run banks, outright purchases.China might now have to take the "tougher route" of developing more of its own technology, with less access to foreign partners and know-how, said Rajiv Biswas, chief Asia economist for IHS Markit."It may be a slower path," Biswas said.The government and companies are pouring billions of dollars into research. Huawei, the telecom equipment giant and China's first global tech brand, spent $15 billion last year - more than Apple Inc.All of this has helped make China an emerging heavyweight in telecoms, artificial intelligence and other fields. Yet the United States, Europe, Japan and other governments complain that Beijing has done so in part by stealing technology or pressuring foreign companies to hand over trade secrets.Washington is pushing Beijing to roll back plans for a government-led creation of global competitors in robotics, electric cars, artificial intelligence and an array of emerging technologies. Beijing's trading partners argue that such plans violate its commitments to further open its vast consumer and business markets.The struggle compounds the challenges for President Xi Jinping's government by threatening to delay or disrupt its economic plans. China's leaders are reluctant to yield; they need higher-tech industries to keep incomes rising. Many producers of textiles, shoes and toys have already migrated to Vietnam, Cambodia and other lower-cost economies.China's ruling Communist Party responded to an economic downturn last year by stepping up spending and lending. That effort reversed a campaign to curb reliance on debt, which had soared so high that rating agencies had downgraded China's credit rating for government borrowing.Abroad, Xi has been forced to overhaul his multibillion-dollar "Belt and Road" initiative to build railways and other infrastructure. In response to complaints that some countries are left with too much debt, the government has written off some loans and renegotiated contracts.The tariff war was sparked by years of yawning U.S. trade deficits with China and by complaints - by the Trump administration and many independent trade experts - that Beijing was engaging in predatory and illicit practices, including the theft of technology. The first U.S. penalties targeted high-tech Chinese goods that American officials said benefited from improper support from Beijing.Its impact spread as President Donald Trump extended tariff increases to Chinese exporters of handbags, furniture and other goods. Those higher import taxes heightened the threat of job losses - a political risk for an unelected party that derives its claim to power in no small part from having managed three decades of explosive economic growth.On the surface at least, the impact of Friday's U.S. tariff hike "is relatively modest," Brian Coulton, chief economist for Fitch Ratings, said in a report. But if Trump proceeds with his threat to extend 25% tariffs to all imports from China, that "would be a much more material threat to China's growth outlook," Coulton said."Renewed weakening in China would rekindle financial market concerns about global growth risks," he said.Xi's personal standing has been hurt by slowing growth and by last year's decision to eliminate term limits for his office as president, said Zhang Lifang, an independent political commentator in Beijing."I think these two things are very stressful for him, both economically and politically," Zhang said.The United States and Europe have been increasing the cost and complexity of Chinese acquisition of foreign technology or blocking it outright. In October, the European Union tentatively approved the trade bloc's first rules on foreign investments in sensitive sectors. That step followed criticism of Chinese purchases of European technology vendors that are considered vital national assets, including German robot maker Kuka. Chinese buyers have also acquired Sweden's Volvo Cars, Swiss agri-tech supplier Syngenta and IBM Corp.'s low-end server business.In the United States, Trump vetoed the 2017 purchase of a chipmaker, Lattice Semiconductor, that was financed by a Chinese government fund.Foreign manufacturers of consumer electronics and other goods already are shifting investments to Southeast Asia to cut costs, thereby hurting demand for Chinese parts suppliers and sapping revenue they would use to develop technology."Boardrooms of multinationals, including possibly Chinese companies, might decide they need to have more manufacturing capability outside China to reduce this risk," Biswas said .That shift, accelerated by the pressure from U.S. tariffs, promises a potential windfall for other Asian economies.Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen has suggested that the U.S.-China tariff war might help her government woo back manufacturers who had moved to the mainland in search of lower costs."Our goal is to speed up Taiwanese business people's coming back to rebuild a high added-value supply chain and encourage industries to transform and upgrade themselves," Tsai said.___AP videojournalists Fu Ting in Beijing and Taijing Wu in Taipei contributed to this report.Load-Date: May 13, 2019End of Document

Why tariff war threatens Beijing's global economic ambitionsAssociated Press Financial WireMay 13, 2019 Monday 3:41 AM GMTCopyright 2019 Associated Press All Rights ReservedSection: BUSINESS NEWSLength: 1036 wordsByline: By JOE McDONALD, AP Business WriterDateline: BEIJING BodyBEIJING (AP) - China's intensified tariff war with the Trump administration is threatening Beijing's ambition to transform itself into the dominant player in global technology.The United States is a vital customer and source of technology for Chinese makers of electronics, medical equipment and other high-tech exports - industries that the ruling Communist Party sees as the heart of its economic future.Yet to the Trump administration, they're a threat to America's industrial leadership.Beijing managed to keep Chinese economic growth steady in the most recent quarter despite a drop in exports to the United States. It did so by boosting government spending and bank lending. But China's technology exporters suffered huge sales drops of up to 40 percent, which ate into profits that pay for technology research.The tariff war is compounding the pain felt by many Chinese companies. They are already enduring stiffened resistance in the United States and Europe to Chinese acquisitions of technology through joint ventures with foreign companies or, with financing by state-run banks, outright purchases.China might now have to take the "tougher route" of developing more of its own technology, with less access to foreign partners and know-how, said Rajiv Biswas, chief Asia economist for IHS Markit."It may be a slower path," Biswas said.The government and companies are pouring billions of dollars into research. Huawei, the telecom equipment giant and China's first global tech brand, spent $15 billion last year - more than Apple Inc.All of this has helped make China an emerging heavyweight in telecoms, artificial intelligence and other fields. Yet the United States, Europe, Japan and other governments complain that Beijing has done so in part by stealing technology or pressuring foreign companies to hand over trade secrets.Washington is pushing Beijing to roll back plans for a government-led creation of global competitors in robotics, electric cars, artificial intelligence and an array of emerging technologies. Beijing's trading partners argue that such plans violate its commitments to further open its vast consumer and business markets.The struggle compounds the challenges for President Xi Jinping's government by threatening to delay or disrupt its economic plans. China's leaders are reluctant to yield; they need higher-tech industries to keep incomes rising. Many producers of textiles, shoes and toys have already migrated to Vietnam, Cambodia and other lower-cost economies.China's ruling Communist Party responded to an economic downturn last year by stepping up spending and lending. That effort reversed a campaign to curb reliance on debt, which had soared so high that rating agencies had downgraded China's credit rating for government borrowing.Abroad, Xi has been forced to overhaul his multibillion-dollar "Belt and Road" initiative to build railways and other infrastructure. In response to complaints that some countries are left with too much debt, the government has written off some loans and renegotiated contracts.The tariff war was sparked by years of yawning U.S. trade deficits with China and by complaints - by the Trump administration and many independent trade experts - that Beijing was engaging in predatory and illicit practices, including the theft of technology. The first U.S. penalties targeted high-tech Chinese goods that American officials said benefited from improper support from Beijing.Its impact spread as President Donald Trump extended tariff increases to Chinese exporters of handbags, furniture and other goods. Those higher import taxes heightened the threat of job losses - a political risk for an unelected party that derives its claim to power in no small part from having managed three decades of explosive economic growth.On the surface at least, the impact of Friday's U.S. tariff hike "is relatively modest," Brian Coulton, chief economist for Fitch Ratings, said in a report. But if Trump proceeds with his threat to extend 25% tariffs to all imports from China, that "would be a much more material threat to China's growth outlook," Coulton said."Renewed weakening in China would rekindle financial market concerns about global growth risks," he said.Xi's personal standing has been hurt by slowing growth and by last year's decision to eliminate term limits for his office as president, said Zhang Lifang, an independent political commentator in Beijing."I think these two things are very stressful for him, both economically and politically," Zhang said.The United States and Europe have been increasing the cost and complexity of Chinese acquisition of foreign technology or blocking it outright. In October, the European Union tentatively approved the trade bloc's first rules on foreign investments in sensitive sectors. That step followed criticism of Chinese purchases of European technology vendors that are considered vital national assets, including German robot maker Kuka. Chinese buyers have also acquired Sweden's Volvo Cars, Swiss agri-tech supplier Syngenta and IBM Corp.'s low-end server business.In the United States, Trump vetoed the 2017 purchase of a chipmaker, Lattice Semiconductor, that was financed by a Chinese government fund.Foreign manufacturers of consumer electronics and other goods already are shifting investments to Southeast Asia to cut costs, thereby hurting demand for Chinese parts suppliers and sapping revenue they would use to develop technology."Boardrooms of multinationals, including possibly Chinese companies, might decide they need to have more manufacturing capability outside China to reduce this risk," Biswas said .That shift, accelerated by the pressure from U.S. tariffs, promises a potential windfall for other Asian economies.Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen has suggested that the U.S.-China tariff war might help her government woo back manufacturers who had moved to the mainland in search of lower costs."Our goal is to speed up Taiwanese business people's coming back to rebuild a high added-value supply chain and encourage industries to transform and upgrade themselves," Tsai said.___AP videojournalists Fu Ting in Beijing and Taijing Wu in Taipei contributed to this report.Load-Date: May 13, 2019End of Document

Break with Google truncates Huawei to have the best selling smartphonesCE Noticias Financieras EnglishMay 20, 2019 MondayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 844 wordsBody Hong Kong (CNN Business)  Google is restricting Huawei's access to its operating system and Android apps after the Trump administration put the Chinese technology firm on the blacklist.  The decision is a hard blow for Huawei whose goal is to be the main brand of smartphones by the end of 2020.  The Trump administration banned last week for US companies to sell products to Huawei without the approval of the US government in a significant escalation of the trade dispute with China.  "We are complying with the order and reviewing the implications," a Google spokesperson said Monday.  Huawei, the second largest smartphone sales in the world, depends on a series of Google services for its devices, including the Android operating system and the Google Play app store.  The Silicon Valley giant will suspend much of that access according to several reports after Washington placed Huawei on a list of foreign companies that are thought to undermine US national security or have foreign policy interests. Companies on the list are prohibited from receiving components and software unless their business is licensed.  Existing Huawei phones will not be affected  Huawei will only be able to use the public version of Android and will not have access to Google apps and services. The news was reported for the first time by Reuters.  Google said that consumers who already have Huawei smartphones will not be very affected by now.  We recommend:  "Google Play and the security protections of Google Play Protect will continue to work on existing Huawei devices," the spokesman added without providing further details.  The ban jeopardizes Huawei's supply chain and could delay the implementation of 5G services around the world. But the most immediate problem for Huawei is what the decision implies for the future sales of their smartphones.  Most of Google's popular products, such as Gmail, YouTube and Google Maps are banned in China, where Huawei offers local alternatives such as WeChat from Tencent and Baidu Maps. But the company is deeply dependent on other countries outside of China.  Approximately half of its smartphone sales last year were outside China, according to researchers Canalys and IDC.  Huawei said it is "examining the implications of US actions for consumers," adding that it will continue to provide "security updates and after-sales services" for all existing smartphones and tablets, including its low-cost brand Honor.  China's response: "Wait to see"  The Chinese technology company said it has spent at least three years working on its own operating system.  "Huawei has been generating an alternative operating system if necessary," said Huawei spokesman Glenn Schloss. "We would like to continue operating in the ecosystems of Microsoft and Google," he added.  Huawei licenses Microsoft's operating system for its laptops and tablets. Microsoft did not immediately respond to a request for comment.  Beijing has repeatedly criticized the US campaign against Huawei, calling the addition of the company to the political decision blacklist.  "China supports Chinese companies that defend their legitimate rights in accordance with the law," Lu Kang, spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, told a news conference on Monday.  "In terms of the measures that the Chinese companies or government will take, please wait and see," he said.  Eliminate Huawei out ofChina?  Being isolated from the Google ecosystem would be a huge blow to Huawei's ambitions to surpass Samsung as the world's leading producer of smartphones.  The consumer business that includes smartphones, laptops, tablets and wearable devices such as smart watches, was the main contributor to Huawei's profits last year. The division generated almost 50 billion dollars in 2018, which represents more than 45% of its revenues.  For millions of users outside of China, being isolated from Google apps and services "kills the attractiveness of a Huawei phone," said IDC analyst Bryan Ma.  Read also:  "It eliminates the utility of a Huawei phone outside China, leaving them dead in the water," he added.  Theoretically, Huawei can try to win over consumers with their competitive hardware and innovation, and then convince them to download Google apps after they buy the Huawei phone, said Nicole Peng, an analyst at Canalys.  But the evidence shows that "post-sale facilities are very complex for users, unless they know what they are doing," Peng said.  In addition, when customers discover that Huawei can not get the Google ecosystem on their phones "it will affect trust, they will question if there is something wrong with the device," he added.  Even if customers could download Google apps independently on Huawei phones, the phones would still not have access to the so-called Google Mobile Services.  Many third-party applications such as shared-travel platforms and food deliveries depend on services like Google Maps. Most of these apps may not be supported on Huawei devices, said IDC Ma.  Without that access, "the Huawei phone is a brick," he said. Load-Date: May 20, 2019End of Document

Senate Finance Subcommittee Issues Testimony From American Enterprise InstituteTargeted News ServiceJune 12, 2019 Wednesday 1:17 AM  ESTCopyright 2019 Targeted News Service LLC All Rights ReservedLength: 2591 wordsByline: Targeted News ServiceDateline: WASHINGTON BodyThe Senate Finance subcommittee on International Trade, Customs and Global Competitiveness issued the following testimony by Derek Scissors, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, at a hearing entitled "China's Belt and Road Initiative":"There are a number of easy myths to dispel about China's Belt and Road Initiative. It's worth trillions - false. China is buying up the participating countries - if so, only in self-defeating fashion. The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is primarily about transportation - reasonable but still mostly wrong."Perhaps the most important mistake is that the BRI represents a growing Chinese footprint globally. It did in 2016, not now. More countries are joining the BRI in name but the extent of activity is shrinking. Moreover, inadequate foreign currency reserves means Beijing will be hard pressed to keep the BRI afloat as a global commercial effort. It is therefore likely to devolve toward a talk shop with substantial resources assigned only to a small set of priority countries."The first implication for American policy of this likely BRI trajectory is: do not overreact. The second is to identify the much smaller group of countries China will favor going to forward. Our interests are very different than the PRC's and the BRI does not appear to call for any substantial American response on economic grounds (only).Facts On The BRI's Past and Present"Data on the BRI are drawn from the American Enterprise Institute's China Global Investment Tracker, the only publically available compilation of Chinese investment and construction globally.1 The Tracker presently includes over 3000 transactions compiled from 2005-2018, each valued at $95 million or more. It does not capture the lending which usually supports the investment and construction transactions."What countries are actually in the BRI and which subset of projects should be counted are open questions, as Beijing has deliberately left the BRI ill-defined. "BRI projects are only the good ones" is not far off from the Chinese position. When the initiative was launched in 2013, it was said to include 64 countries. More have been added, most famously Italy. In statistical notes, the Ministry of Commerce never uses even the original 64, the number instead bizarrely varying between 49 and 55 or not mentioned at all.2"The Tracker's view of the BRI is based on the official Chinese government website, using all projects in all countries profiled.3 The intention is to get the largest numbers possible, numbers which can only overstate the impact of the BRI to date, yet still turn out to be on the small side."At time of writing, 137 countries were profiled on the BRI site."From 2014 to 2018, total Chinese investment in all BRI countries was $190 billion. Again, this is a deliberately high estimate. At this rate, it will take until 2040 for investment to reach the $1 trillion goal often bandied about - if this is a new Marshall Plan, it's a slow one. It's also not especially vital to the PRC. Sizing it as aggressively as possible, the BRI comprised less than 30 percent of total investment and less than combined Chinese investment in the US, Australia, and United Kingdom over this period."Investment is not the main economic activity in the BRI, construction is. Chinese construction activity in the full set of BRI countries was worth twice as much, at $388 billion for 2014-8."(While construction is heavily financed by Chinese loans, it does not involve any ownership of assets and therefore does not qualify as investment. It is properly categorized as part of services trade.) The construction figures are impressive but, at this pace, it would still take 50 years for the BRI to be the $6-trillion program some anticipate.4"What is being built and, to a lesser extent, bought? Road-, rail-, and port-building win the most attention but are nosed out by power plant construction. In investment, energy dominates."By country, the investment pattern within the BRI reflects that of Chinese investment in all countries: greater foreign wealth draws more Chinese money. Tiny Singapore leads by a substantial margin because it is rich and there is money to be made there. Construction goes first to heavily populated developing economies, which naturally have the most available projects.The BRI's Future"What the BRI has been to now is often mildly exaggerated, where it is headed is in some cases greatly exaggerated. Investment volume and growth peaked in 2015. Though construction transactions are publicized more gradually and 2018 figures are certainly not final, volume and growth looks to have peaked in 2016. Rather than building toward global transformation, the BRI may have already seen its most dynamic days."For the first half of 2019, all results are of course incomplete for investment and nowhere close to complete for construction. But Chinese investment around the world appears to have dropped again, after dropping sharply in the second half of 2018. The reason is plunging investment by state-owned enterprises (SOEs), which had until last autumn unfailingly outspent private Chinese enterprises. For roughly eight months, major state investors have either reported drastically less global investment for some reason or actually cut their spending."While that is a global trend, it is telling for the BRI. In 2014-8, SOEs accounted for about 73 percent of BRI investment. They accounted for about 96 percent of construction, which is utterly dominated by giants such as State Construction Engineering and PowerChina and their many subsidiaries. The BRI is a program of SOEs. Private companies avoid BRI construction because there's no financial return to often-difficult projects in what are mostly poorer countries. The same is true to a lesser extent for investment."It is no surprise, then, that the official BRI investment tally for January through April 2019 was tallied for just 50 countries and stood at just $4.6 billion.5 No on-year growth was given, which is Chinese for "it's declining and we don't want to say that." If SOEs have stopped disclosing some BRI activities, it obviously harms transparency and raises questions about Beijing's commitment. If SOEs have stopped investing, the questions become pointed: the PRC is a reliable partner, until it needs a break?"The SOE pause has weight because it can be traced back to serious problems in Chinese external finance. When Xi Jinping launched the BRI in September 2013, China's foreign exchange reserves were valued at $3.66 trillion.6 They rose to $3.99 trillion in June 2014, then began falling, standing at $3.09 trillion at the end of April 2019. There is also a smaller amount of foreign currency held in the state banking system which appears to have fallen more steeply. The"BRI was launched under conditions of not only abundant but also fast-rising reserves. They are still abundant but the trend has reversed."Reserves are what make the BRI go. While China and others fuss over the yuan becoming a globally used currency, the share of the yuan in global transactions is about two percent, with most of those in Hong Kong. For global reserve holdings, the yuan is about as important as the Canadian dollar.7 BRI governments and local businesses want dollars or other hard currency from Beijing, hard currency which it increasingly cannot spare. Unless the foreign exchange pattern of the past five years is flipped, the BRI as a global program will slowly starve to death."Adding a bit more pressure, if only a bit, is internal financial failure. The PRC pushed domestic outstanding credit - an aggregate debt measure -- from $6.5 trillion in 2008 to $33.2 trillion in 2018, mocking all claims of recent economic success.8 But this is not money used for the BRI."To protect fragile banks, Beijing still employs a closed capital account, which keeps domestic and foreign funds separate (and money from freely leaving the country). A secondary impact: weak growth from heavy debt gradually undermines the BRI by making it politically sensitive.US Policy On the BRI"The first question for American policy-makers is a surprise but follows directly from current conditions: what is it worth to the US to kill the BRI? In most situations, for instance with regard to intellectual property, the US does not have the ability to halt Chinese actions outright. With the BRI, we effectively do."Balance of payments weakness since 2014 has made the PRC extremely dependent on sales to the US. The PRC's cumulative goods and services surplus with the US from 1999 through 2018 was close to $4.6 trillion, more than its foreign exchange holdings at their peak.9 Moreover, from June 2014 to April 2019, when China's reserves dropped $900 billion, it still ran a $1.5-trillion goods and services surplus with the US. Without that, Beijing cannot avoid a balance of payments crisis, much less fund a global BRI."Enter the trade dispute. Available 2019 data show goods imports from the PRC falling $17 billion from January to March.10 The US has since hiked from 10 to 25 percent tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports, pending exclusions, and a tariff of unknown rate is possible on $300 billion more. Neither action is yet reflected in trade or reserves. Nearly-across-the-board US tariffs, perhaps half 25 percent and half 10 percent, would cost Beijing at least $150 billion in hard currency annually, a loss the PRC can afford for a while but the BRI cannot."The BRI presently depends on American consumers buying Chinese products and can be paralyzed for an extended period just by making those products more expensive. Such actions of course have costs for the US, though they are not especially large (unless combined with 25- percent across-the-board tariffs on Mexico). Is the BRI a sufficient threat on its own to justify fairly minor sanctions against China? Not on the commercial side."With regard to frequently cited "debt traps," Beijing can no longer afford the billions in hard currency needed to spring a trap. The clearest illustration: there turns out to be nothing Venezuela can provide worth what China has risked. A deeper answer involves assets the PRC might acquire for debt forgiveness. In most cases, there are no commercially valuable assets available, hence the initial involvement of heavily subsidized SOEs instead of profit-motivated multinationals. In Sri Lanka, for example, the obvious pieces for China to gain are infrastructure projects for which there is little supporting demand.11"The idea behind debt traps, however, is relevant more broadly: what does Beijing gain from the BRI to justify devoting (increasingly) precious resources? The PRC faces rising labor and land costs, making its exports particularly less competitive in lower-income countries that dominate the BRI. Better transport and logistics can boost demand there. The stress on energy reinforces China's interest in commodities extraction and shipment, from Russia and other oil suppliers primarily and metal ore suppliers such as Vietnam and Chile secondarily."The US should care little about either exports to poor BRI countries or competitive commodities extraction. American exports skew heavily to NAFTA partners and Europe. Net American oil and oil products imports in the first quarter of 2019 were less than 10% of those in the first quarter of 2009 and metals imports have never been sizable.12 It makes no sense for the US to mirror Chinese economic priorities, much less dubious actions like subsidizing power plant construction in Laos."This discussion is limited to economic issues and security concerns may be much sharper."Economics can inform those concerns, as well. China cannot fund a truly global BRI and odds are better that financial constraints will tighten rather than loosen. Beijing will inevitably focus on what it sees as the most important countries. On economic grounds, these are the richer countries in Southeast Asia for export markets and the Arab world for oil. American policy should anticipate where China's gaze will finally land and evaluate to what extent this very select set of countries calls for a US response. The BRI as a whole has become a red herring."* * *Footnotes:1 American Enterprise Institute and Heritage Foundation, "China Global Investment Tracker," Not at all. The China trade talks. Of course a deal would be a positive for the markets. By the way, with the tariffs on cars coming out of Mexico, I don't --I have no idea man where that came from, but he does -- he has tariff as they said.BARTIROMO: Look, look, he's trying to come up with whatever lever he can to put the Mexico officials on notice, that he needs help with the order.MCDOWELL: And delay closing the border, which I think was the reason that he said that.BARTIROMO: I think he's backpedalling on that one.MCDOWELL: Yes.BARTIROMO: Yes. A lot of criticism on that. And huge impact to the economy.MCDOWELL: Right. Exactly.BARTIROMO: We're going to take a short break. When we come back, we'll be covering the very latest on the March Jobs Report this morning. We got full coverage beginning at 8:00 a.m. Eastern, all hands on deck, so do join us for that. But first, dividing assets, Jeff and MacKenzie Bezos finalizing their divorce, splitting up the billion dollar plus Empire. We've got the numbers for you coming up next.And then the New York Jets reveal new uniforms for 2019, but the Twitter universe not reacting kindly. This morning, we will show you what the reaction is and the uniforms coming up.BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, the divorce is final. Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos and his wife, MacKenzie, agreeing to a settlement that divides their shares of Amazon. Under the agreement, Jeff will own 12 percent of Amazon stop valued at $170 billion. MacKenzie will own four percent value at $35 billion making her the third richest woman in the world. So, she'll keep a quarter of the overall stock that they own currently.In addition, Jeff Bezos will keep voting power on MacKenzie stock and will retain full ownership of The Washington Post and Blue Origin. MacKenzie said in a statement yesterday that she is going to be talking about this in the future and that she is happy to hold just a quarter of his stocks.Joining us right now is Trial Attorney, Misty Marris, rather, pardon me, to talk more about that. And Misty, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.MISTY MARRIS, TRIAL ATTORNEY: Thank you for having me.BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the details here?MARRIS: Look, I think that this is a lightning speed settlement, when you're talking about the astronomer amount of assets that were in play.BARTIROMO: Yes.MARRIS: That tells me that there was great painstaking to make sure stock holders are not going to film nervous. Nothing makes a stockholder more leery, then the prospect of litigation that could go on for years and years and years. Especially after we saw these tweets about how, you know, they had happy marriage. And everyone's happy to move forward, that is certainly part of the intent here, to make sure stockholders are feeling good about the company.BARTIROMO: Yes. What did you think about it?MURPHY: But I guess the settlement though gives -- it's fair enough. I mean there's plenty of money there, you could ask for another billion --MCDOWELL: Wait a minute.MURPHY: -- or another 10 grand.MCDOWELL: Half. I want half.BARTIROMO: I don't know. I --MCDOWELL: I quote Eddie Murphy, half.MARRIS: You make a great point though because she has all of the legal arguments to get half under these circumstances.BARTIROMO: She said she (INAUDIBLE)MURPHY: I'll take an eighth. I'm on the other side of Dagen. I'll get -- I'll take an eighth.(CROSSTALK)BARTIROMO: She's happy to take a quarter, but we're joking about it, but why is she taking a quarter and not half?MARRIS: I think that that's because she had all of the legal arguments to take up. There was no prenup. They're in Washington State, which is a community property, which means ultimately, if she wanted to go to court, she would be entitled to half the asset. So, the only reason that you're not going to go for that is because you want to split perhaps amicably and again I think it's in both of their interest that Amazon isn't negatively impacted by this.BARTIROMO: Yes. And he's going to -- he's going to keep 75 percent of this stock. You're right, it's all about what -- he probably convinced her, "Well, look, we don't want a massive market selloff.MARRIS: Right. Absolutely. And he's retaining voting power so it's not different for the investors. Right? So everything is going to be pretty much the same for them, he's just giving up a certain percentage of his of his stock.BARTIROMO: Yes.MCDOWELL: We don't know how the properties are being split up, but I don't think they own $35 billion in (AUDIO GAP) her, which would double her value of the stake in the company. And she also had a role in the company when it was being founded.BARTIROMO: And that's why.MCDOWELL: So, it's --BARTIROMO: She had every argument to go for more if she wanted to.MARRIS: Yes. But I think it's also the family, too. I mean they were very strong about they're going into this co-parenting together.MCDOWELL: Yes.BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right.MARRIS: So, yes. It's a (INAUDIBLE)BARTIROMO: Children shouldn't suffer. Misty Marris, thank you so much.BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Friday, April 5th, your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast.It's job's Friday, jobs in America, the March jobs report out in 8:00 a.m. Eastern, two hours from now, the very latest on what it shows about the economy right now, and will it move markets? We are all over it. Ahead of the numbers, Futures have a firmer tone this morning.We're looking at a rally at the start of trading, Dow Industrials up about 30 points right now, S&P 500 up 4, and the NASDAQ up 15 points, a quarter of a percent. Yesterday, the market was up, Dow Industrials up 166-1/2 points, fueled by advances in trade-sensitive stocks from Dow and Boeing.The S&P added just under six points, but the NASDAQ gave back a bit, down three points at the close, yesterday.In Europe this morning, take a look at the indices, we've got the European markets mixed, FT 100 is up about 11 points, CAC Quarante is up 12, but the DAX Index in Germany down 7, this morning.Shares mostly higher in Asia, overnight, U.S.-China trade talks in Washington, making progress, as a result, you did see some firmness. Japan, the big winner, Nikkei Average up just a fraction, but Chinese markets in Shanghai -- the Shanghai and the Hong Kong, Hang Seng Index closed, overnight.Deadline missed, Chicago, ready to take action after actor Jussie Smollett missed a deadline to pay for the cost of the investigation, into the alleged assault on the actor, the city's next step, coming up, and major jewelry stores closing their doors, more on Kay, Zales and Jared, this morning.Plus, the New York Jets' new look, the team reveals it's 2019 uniforms and Twitter had a very quick response, as you'd expect, we're going to bring it to you.First this, though, NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg in Washington, this week, meeting with President Trump, the two discussing NATO funding, the Russian threat, and the rise of China on the global stage.I sat down with Secretary Stoltenberg to talk about these issues and more, and we began with his historic address to Congress, as NATO marks 70 years, this week.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)JENS STOLTENBERG, SECRETARY GENERAL, NATO: Well, NATO is, by far, the longest lasting alliance in history, but also the most successful alliance in history because we have been able to preserve peace and safeguard freedom for 70 years.This is, of course, great importance for Europe, but it's also important for the United States, because through NATO, the United States has more friends and more allies than any other power.(END VIDEO CLIP)BARTIROMO: The President of the United States certainly noted in a somewhat more of a combative way that many NATO members are not paying their fair share. Since the President voiced his concern, have you seen a big change?STOLTENBERG: What we have seen is that the clear message from President Trump on defense spending on burden sharing is having a real impact because all NATO allies have now started to invest more. European allies in Canada have added since 2016, $41 billion extra to the defense budget. And by the end of next year, this figure will rise to $100 billion. So, this is making NATO stronger.BARTIROMO: And, of course, at the very beginning, the creation of NATO, it was really to shield against aggression, aggressive nations, in particular, the Soviet Union. So, assess for us, Russia, because we have a situation now, where many people believe that Russia is trying to replace the United States as the main outside force within the Middle East.And of course, is doing deals in European nations and many times being questioned in terms of its loyalty to the globe, in terms of alliances. How do you see Russia today?STOLTENBERG: NATO has to deal with a more assertive Russia, because you have seen that Russia has heavily invested in more than military equipment, including nuclear weapons. They have used military force against neighbors, Georgia and Ukraine.They are increasing their presence in the Middle East, and they're also using cyber and what we call hybrid tactics to try to meddle into our democratic processes.All of this is of great concern and therefore, NATO has implemented the biggest reinforcements our (INAUDIBLE) defense since the end of the Cold War, with higher end forces, with combat ready troops in the Eastern part of the alliance.And also, modernizing the whole command structure how NATO is working because we need to be able to respond and to -- and to maintain credible deterrence and defense when we see a more assertive Russia.BARTIROMO: Yes, which is why the President has questioned the arrangement where Germany is getting, for example, gas, from Russia. Shouldn't Germany be looking toward a NATO member, an alliance partner, like the United States, for such a purchase?STOLTENBERG: NATO allies realize that energy price has security implications and therefore, we welcome that allies are attempting to diversify their supplies of energy. We are seeing some allies really making progress, for instance, Poland and Lithuania.The issue of the new pipeline from Russia is an issue which divides NATO allies. And NATO is not an energy institution, so we don't make decisions on concrete projects like that. The most important thing is that we see that allies are stepping up and Germany is part of that.Germany leads one of our battle groups in the Eastern part of the alliance, in Lithuania, and Germany is also increasing defense spending as response to ever more demanding security environment that (INAUDIBLE)BARTIROMO: Well, I'm glad you mentioned that, Germany increasing defense spending. Because the defense increases in NATO defense increases will total close to $100 billion by the end of 2019. Yet, Germany is now forecasting a reduction in their defense budget.Are you comfortable with that and that other Germany -- and those other members will meet that two percent target?STOLTENBERG: I expect that all allies, including Germany, make, you know, make good on the promise we all made together, and that is to increase defense spending, improve burden sharing within the alliance. Germany has started to increase.We have seen health increases in the last years, and also the proposed budget for next year, for 2020, has an increase in German defense spending or implies increased defense spending in Germany. But I expect them to do more.And this has been one of the main issues that has been discussed at our foreign ministerial meeting in Washington, this week. All allies need to make good on their promises, invest more, and that also -- that's also the case for Germany.BARTIROMO: What about missile defense systems and military equipment, for example, your position on Turkey, given the fact that it's acquiring the Russian's S-400 missile defense system? If there were a confrontation between NATO and Russia, is it not likely that Russia would deny Turkey the necessary spare parts to sustain that S-400 system?STOLTENBERG: The S-400 system will not, in any way, be part of the integrated NATO air and missile defense system. That's not possible to integrate into our system. Second, NATO provide support for Turkey. We augment their air defenses with patriot batteries and also, an Italian- French systems anti deployed by Italy and Turkey.So, we already provide support to Turkey when it comes to air defense, but we also recognize that the issue of S-400 is an issue that creates divisions, especially between Turkey and the United States. And we support efforts to try to find a solution.And NATO is a platform for allies to meet and to sit down, and to address issues like, for instance, the S-400 procurement.BARTIROMO: Secretary Mike Pompeo just back, recently, from Europe, talking about the China threat, in particular, Huawei, where many nations there, including Poland, have the Huawei infrastructure which has been said to be really an espionage platform for the Chinese government. What are your thoughts on the threat of the rising China situation?STOLTENBERG: China is a rising power with a growing economy, investing heavily in new military capabilities, and we're also seeing that China is coming closer to Europe, to NATO allies, in Europe, in cyberspace, in the arctic, in the Mediterranean.And several NATO allies have expressed concerns about also Huawei and Chinese investments in critical infrastructure. And we take these concerns very seriously, and that's also the reason why NATO allies had to address the security implications of the rise of China.At the same time, we believe there's a potential for also a partnership with China, and our military and Chinese military and NATO military have met and have looked into ways also to work together.BARTIROMO: Explain the threat of Huawei. Assess the situation for us, because, you know, the European nations have pushed back. Certainly, you see what's taking place in Italy, for one, also Poland said look, we -- you know, we are worried about Huawei.And yet, Germany is talking about the fact that they can't dismantle the Huawei infrastructure and build another one. It's too expensive. What is the specific threat around Huawei?STOLTENBERG: This has traditionally been an issue, which has been related to economy, to trade, to investments, which is not a NATO responsibility. At the same time, we all understand that infrastructure -- investments and infrastructure can also have security implications, and therefore, NATO has developed some guidelines for the resilience of critical infrastructure.And now, NATO says those guidelines also, which I say when it comes to investments in, for instance, 5G networks. So, this is an issue which is important for all NATO allies. And we also discussed it with the European Union.BARTIROMO: When I spoke with Secretary Pompeo recently, he said look, if the Europeans continue to use the Huawei infrastructure, we will have to share less information with them. That was quite telling if the U.S. is going to hold back on key information with allies. Do you agree that's the right move?STOLTENBERG: Well, that's one of the examples of the concerns that allies have expressed, and the United States has been very clear on this issue, but as I said, this is not an issue which is discussed among NATO allies and also within the European Union.And this is an ongoing discussion based on the concerns which several nations have expressed related to these kinds of new technologies.BARTIROMO: Mr. Secretary, you had a meeting with the President, this past week. Can you tell us about it? Are these the priorities that you discussed with the President?STOLTENBERG: It was a useful and good meeting with President Trump. We discussed a wide range of issues, especially the importance of burden- sharing, making NATO a fair alliance, where allies invest more in defense. And I told them about their progress, $100 billion that will come into the defense budgets of European allies and Canada.And, of course, I also told him about the need to do even more. We also discussed Afghanistan and the importance of trying not to create the conditions for a peaceful negotiated solution, but also making sure that Afghanistan doesn't, once again, become a safe haven for international terrorists.That was the reason why I went into Afghanistan, preventing that country from being a kind of a launch pad for new attacks against United States or the NATO allies. And then also, of course, Russia, Russia is now in violation of the INF treaty, a treaty that has banned all intermediate range weapons, Russia violates that by deploying new missiles. And this is of great concern for all NATO allies.BARTIROMO: So, what is the answer to this? How do you fight back? This has come up several times, and yet Russia is moving on its way and moving forward with its own plans.STOLTENBERG: Our answer is what we call a dual track approach, and that is strong deterrence, strong defense combined with dialogue. We have to show Russia that if they want to confront us, we are ready and we are united and we are firm.But at the same time, we are open for dialogue with Russia. Russia is our neighbor, Russia's here to stay. We need to strive for a better relationship with Russia, but we also need to engage with Russia or to talk to Russia on issues like arms-control.BARTIROMO: Mr. Secretary, it's good to see you, thanks so much for joining us today.STOLTENBERG: Thank you so much for having me.(END VIDEOTAPE)BARTIROMO: All right, Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg there. Tune in at 7:00 a.m. Eastern this morning, for my first on FOX interview with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. He is going to join us, give us an update on China and the border, as well.Coming up, giving up on malls, more Kay, Zales and Jared jewelry stores closed.
