Former Chinese Interpol chief 'admits his crimes' of accepting $2m bribesCNN WireJune 20, 2019 Thursday 1:06 PM GMTCopyright 2019 Cable News Network All Rights ReservedLength: 295 wordsByline: By Steven Jiang, CNNDateline: BEIJING (CNN) BodyBEIJING (CNN) --  Interpol's former president Meng Hongwei, who dramatically vanished into police custody after returning to China in 2018, has admitted to corruption charges in a court in Tianjin, Chinese state media reported Thursday.Meng, who was also China's vice minister of public security, was accused of accepting more than $2 million (14.46 million yuan) from businesses and individuals from 2005 to 2017, according to state media outlets Xinhua and People's Daily.In Meng's closing remarks, after arguments from both sides were heard, he "admitted his crimes and expressed repentance," state media reported. The court's verdict and Meng's sentencing will be announced at a later date.Meng disappeared after he left Interpol headquarters in France and took a flight back to China in late September 2018. His wife, Grace, said at the time that the last contact she received from him was a text message saying to wait for his call, followed minutes later by a knife emoji.As his case drew rising global attention, the Chinese government acknowledged in October that Meng had been detained for alleged corruption."(Meng) insisted on taking the wrong path and had only himself to blame (for his downfall)," the country's top law enforcement official, Zhao Kezhi, was quoted as saying in a statement.Shortly after Beijing announced Meng's arrest, Interpol said it had received and accepted his resignation with "immediate effect."Meng was the first Chinese official to lead the international policing body and his appointment three years ago in 2016 was greeted enthusiastically by the country's state media. He retained the title of vice-minister of public security while at Interpol.TM & © 2019 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. All rights reserved.Load-Date: June 21, 2019End of Document

PUBG Mobile is now reportedly the world s highest-grossing mobile gameiCrowdNewswire (English)June 20, 2019 Thursday 4:57 PM GMTCopyright 2019 iCrowdNewswire, LLC All Rights ReservedLength: 609 wordsBody                   PUBG Mobile is not only the most popular mobile game in the world, with more than 100 million monthly players, it's now also the top grossing: collecting more than $146 million last month in revenue according to analyst figures reported by The Financial Times. The money comes not only from items and skins bought by players in PUBG Mobile (which was ... Continue reading PUBG Mobile is now reportedly the world's highest-grossing mobile game       PUBG Mobile is not only the most popular mobile game in the world, with more than 100 million monthly players, it's now also the top grossing: collecting more than $146 million last month in revenue according to analyst figures reported by The Financial Times.            The money comes not only from items and skins bought by players in PUBG Mobile (which was adapted from the South Korean PC original by Chinese tech giant Tencent), but also from money spent in the game's China-only rebrand, Game For Peace.            According to estimates from Chinese brokerage Great Wall Securities, PUBG Mobile generated $76 million in revenue last month while Game For Peacegenerated $70 million.            The latter title was published in May by Tencent after Chinese government regulators rejected PUBG Mobile for monetization. Game For Peace is essentially a skinned version of PUBG Mobile with a patriotic setting and less bloodshed. Instead of dying in a pool of blood when eliminated from the game, for example, players get up and wave goodbye.                                                                                                                   Svend Joscelyne@SvendJoscelyne                                                                                                                     They changed PUBG Mobile in China to comply with stricter game violence laws. Now when you  kill' someone they give you a loot box and wave goodbye and honestly it's just so hilariously wholesome                                        33.1K                                                                                3:19 PM   May 8, 2019                                                                                                              12.2K people are talking about this                                                   Twitter Ads info and privacy                                                                 These changes illustrate the difficulties facing gaming companies in China, where the government has cracked down on titles it sees as anti-social or corrupting.            In February, the government regulator stopped approving new licenses for video games altogether, while existing titles have had to be rewritten or incorporate time limits. In 2017, for example, Tencent's last smash hit mobile game, the fantasy MOBA Honor of Kings, limited children under 12 to one hour of daily play, and children aged 12 to 18 to two hours.            Analysts have worried that these restrictions will crimp revenue for companies like Tencent, particularly with its rebrand of Game For Peace. But these latest figures suggest the company has managed to retain its audience. The $146 million combined monthly revenue of Game for Peace and PUBG Mobile now exceeds the $125 million collected by Honor of Kings over that same period.            Tags:              See Campaign: https://www.theverge.com/2019/6/11/18660985/pubg-mobile-monthly-revenue-players-highest-grossing-mobile-game       Contact Information:       James Vincent       Tags:       ,            Artificial Intelligence Newswire,            Wire,            United States,            EnglishLoad-Date: June 20, 2019End of Document

PETER SHOR WINS 2018 MICIUS QUANTUM PRIZEStates News ServiceApril 26, 2019 FridayCopyright 2019 States News ServiceLength: 699 wordsByline: States News ServiceDateline: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. BodyThe following information was released by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT):Shor awarded the $150,000 prize, named after a fifth-century B.C. Chinese scientist, for his groundbreaking theoretical work in the field of quantum computation.Sandi Miller | Department of MathematicsPeter Shor, the Morss Professor of Applied Mathematics at MIT, has received the 2018 Micius Quantum Prize, which is awarded within the field of quantum computation.Shor was nominated for his groundbreaking theoretical work on the factoring algorithm and quantum error correction. Shor, who received his PhD in applied mathematics from MIT in 1985 under the direction of Tom Leighton, is known for his work on quantum computation. Shor's algorithm is a groundbreaking integer-factoring algorithm that he developed in the mid-1990s, which proves a quantum computer can calculate the prime factors of a large number exponentially faster than a classical computer."Peter Shor's quantum algorithms, starting from his factoring algorithm known as Shor's algorithm has revolutionized the field of quantum computing," says Michel Goemans, department head and professor of mathematics. "One could even say that the field would never have taken off without his deep and significant contributions to it."The algorithm is designed to use a quantum computer to quickly break through the RSA (Rivest-Shamir-Adelman) encryption algorithm, which is based on the difficulty of prime factorization, a major concern for the security of classical computing systems. Shor also introduced quantum error-correcting codes and fault-tolerant quantum computation to protect quantum states against decoherence and noise.He will receive 1 million Chinese yuan (about $150,000) as part of his award, which he expects to put toward his continued research into quantum cryptography and quantum information theory. One idea: "I'm thinking about how quantum information relates to black holes," he says.More importantly, says Shor, the Micius Quantum Prize "will draw a lot of attention to the field.""It's an exciting time," he says. "The U.S. government and the Chinese government are putting a lot of money into quantum computing. Experimentalists are starting to build quantum computers that are reaching the point where they can't be simulated by digital computers. People are building very small prototypes, as experiments to see how big quantum computers will behave."Shor has received many other awards for his quantum computing research, including the Dirac Medal of the International Centre for Theoretical Physics, the IEEE Eric E. Sumner Award, for Outstanding Contributions to Communications Technology, and the Nevanlinna Prize. He also is affiliated with the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL) and the Center for Theoretical Physics.The Micius Quantum Prize recognizes significant science advances ranging from early conceptual contributions to recent experimental breakthroughs in the field of quantum communications, quantum simulation, quantum computation, and quantum metrology. Funded by private entrepreneurs, the Micius Quantum Foundation was named after the fifth-century B.C. Chinese scientist who is also known as Mozi who used a pinhole to discover that light travels in straight lines, and who wrote an earlier version of what later became Newton's first law of motion.Other 2018 Micius laureates are Juan Ignacio Cirac, David Deutsch, and Peter Zoller, for their theoretical work on quantum algorithms and physical architectures of quantum computers and simulators; and Rainer Blatt and David Wineland, for experiments that demonstrated fundamental elements of quantum computing with trapped ions.The 2019 Micius Quantum Prizes were also announced within the field of quantum communication: Charles Bennett, Gilles Brassard, Artur Ekert, and Stephen Wiesner, for their inventions of quantum cryptography, and Jian-Wei Pan and Anton Zeilinger for experiments that enabled practically secure and large-scale quantum communications.The award ceremony for 2018 and 2019 prizes will be held on Sept. 20, during the International Conference on Emerging Quantum Technologies in Hefei, China.Load-Date: April 27, 2019End of Document

Vodafone found security holes in Huawei devices between 2009 and 2011CE Noticias Financieras EnglishApril 30, 2019 TuesdayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 284 wordsBody       The routers provided by Huawei to Vodafone, and distributed in Italy, will have presented security holes that allowed the Chinese company to access computers or encrypted data.  Vodafone has revealed to Bloomberg that it has encountered vulnerabilities in Huawei equipment provided for the Italian market, although Vodafone assures that these problems are already resolved.  The UK's largest telecommunications network has identified features in Huawei software that could give the Chinese company unauthorized access to the Italian fixed-line network, a system that makes the Internet available to millions of homes and businesses. This information is contained in documents prepared between 2009 and 2011, consulted by Bloomberg. The same kind of flaws were detected by Vodafone on other networks.  Vodafone asked Huawei to remove these features from the home routers in 2011 and received assurances from the vendor that these faults had been resolved. However, further testing showed otherwise, according to the documents.  The faults detected consisted of the existence of backdoors, which allow you to bypass security and access a computer or encrypted data. Although they are common in some equipment so that technicians can access them, they can also be exploited by outside invaders.  These revelations come at a time when Huawei has been under fire, with accusations coming mainly from the United States. Trump's management has warned that equipment provided by Huawei may be used by the Chinese government for espionage purposes, especially after passage of a law in China that requires companies to cooperate with the government if requested. Chinese technology has denied the allegations. Load-Date: April 30, 2019End of Document

Huawei, the Chinese tech giant embroiled in controversy, just overtook Apple to become the second-largest smartphone maker (AAPL)Business Insider USMay 3, 2019 Friday 03:16 PM GMTCopyright 2019 Insider Inc. All Rights ReservedLength: 1189 wordsByline: leadicicco@businessinsider.com,  (Lisa Eadicicco)Highlight: Huawei has ousted Apple as the second-largest smartphone maker when it comes to quarterly shipments and market share in Q1 2019, a report said.BodyLLUIS GENE/AFP/Getty Image• Huaweihas surpassed            Apple to become the No. 2 smartphone vendor worldwide, according to a new report.• Huawei is thriving as global smartphone sales are continuing to decline.• The company's success comes as it combats accusations of espionage, among other controversies.  • Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.The Chinese electronics giant Huawei has surpassed Apple to become the No. 2 smartphone vendor worldwide, according to statistics from the International Data Corp. (IDC).The milestone comes as smartphone sales are declining globally and Huawei faces ongoing scrutiny regarding the security of its devices and accusations of fraud. Huawei was the only smartphone maker in the top three that saw an increase in shipments in the first quarter of 2019. The company saw year-over-year growth of 50.3% in the first quarter and claimed 19% of the worldwide market share, IDC reported. That puts the company in a strong position to eventually overtake Samsung as the top smartphone vendor and places it ahead of Apple. Smartphone shipments dropped by 30.2% for Apple in the first quarter of 2019 compared with the same period one year ago, IDC reported.Apple holds 11.7% of the worldwide market share as of the first quarter of 2019, while Huawei now claims 19%. That represents a significant change from the first quarter of 2018, when Apple accounted for 15.7% of the worldwide smartphone market share and Huawei claimed just 11.8%.  Samsung saw its volumes drop by 8.1% in the first quarter of 2019, although it still holds the top spot with 23.1% of the global smartphone market.Huawei soars as rivals struggleApple and Samsung aren't the only major companies experiencing the repercussions of a slowing smartphone market. Google said in its recent earnings report that sales of its Pixel smartphone are falling, and LG's mobile division recently            reported first quarter sales of $1.34 billion, down from $2.01 billion in the            same quarter last year. Huawei in March posted record financial results for 2018, with its revenue surpassing $100 billion for the first time, representing a $19.5% year-over-year increase. Its consumer business, which includes smartphones, grew by 45.1% year-on-year in 2018. Part of Huawei's success can be attributed to its wide-ranging product portfolio, which includes both high-end phones, such as its Mate and P lines, and lower-end devices under its Honor offshoot brand. The company's premium models also created a strong brand affiliation for these cheaper products, IDC said.Apple, meanwhile, struggled to keep up with rivals despite its trade-in programs and price cuts in China, particularly as competitors are readying new models with 5G connectivity and foldable designs, IDC said.Read more: Apple is expected to launch 3 new iPhones this year - here's everything we know so farBut market share and smartphone sales aren't the only metrics by which to measure success. Although Huawei claims more of the worldwide smartphone market than Apple, the iPhone maker generated about $266 billion in annual revenue in its 2018 fiscal year, which is more than double Huawei's 2018 revenue.Apple is now shifting its strategy to focus on other product areas, such as services, to offset slowing iPhone sales. Revenue from its services division hit an all-time high of $11.5 billion, the company said in its recent earnings report, and it plans to release a new paid TV service and a gaming service to further boost that product segment. Huawei's ongoing controversiesStill, Huawei's business is booming, even as it faces more scrutiny than ever before around the globe.Earlier this year, US government officials appeared at the Mobile World Congress conference in Barcelona to lobby its European allies not to use Huawei's equipment in their networks. The move came as a result of the ongoing suspicions about whether the company's technologies provide a backdoor for the Chinese government.Huawei has denied these claims, both in its press conference at Mobile World Congress and more recently in its earnings statement."The easiest way to bring down a fortress is to attack it from within," Guo Ping, Huawei's rotating chairman, wrote in the press release. "And the easiest way to reinforce it is from outside. Moving forward, we will do everything we can to shake off outside distractions, improve management, and make progress toward our strategic goals."The Chinese tech behemoth was also indicted on charges related to fraud and trade-secrets conspiracy earlier this year, to which            it pleaded not guilty.Meng Wanzhou, Huawei's chief financial officer, is also awaiting extradition to the US in connection with fraud charges. The Supreme Court of British Columbia in Vancouver has set a date of May 8 for her hearing.Smartphone sales slow as prices increaseHuawei's success comes amid a global decline in the smartphone market.IDC reported that smartphone sales in the first quarter of 2019 were down by 6.6% year-over-year, marking the sixth consecutive quarter of decline. The first year shipments didn't grow was 2017, the former Kleiner Perkins partner May Meeker said in her Internet Trends report in 2018. Smartphone sales boomed between 2011 and 2016, with 2013 proving to be a landmark year as sales of smartphones surpassed feature phones for the first time. But while smartphone adoption has grown, consumers have stopped upgrading their phones as often, especially as smartphones have become increasingly expensive. Read more: Apple says products like the Apple Watch and AirPods are doing so well, its wearables business is as big as a Fortune 200 companyApple's top-of-the-line iPhone XS Max starts at $1,099, while its smaller iPhone XS starts at $999, and the least expensive latest-generation iPhone, the iPhone XR, starts at $750. In 2016, the company's flagship iPhone 7 was priced at $649.Samsung has followed a similar trajectory. The company announced four versions of its flagship Galaxy S10 in February, which range in price from $750 to $1,300, while the Galaxy S7 from 2016 started at $669.99. New smartphone models in recent years have introduced incremental upgrades, making it difficult to convince consumers to pay $1,000 to upgrade to the latest version.Apple is expected to release three iPhones in September, which will reportedly feature new capabilities, such as reverse wireless charging and a triple-lens camera for the high-end model. But Ryan Reith from IDC believes that Huawei is likely to keep its second-place spot this year. "This new ranking of Samsung, Huawei, and Apple is very likely what we'll see when 2019 is all said and done," he wrote. NOW WATCH: Disney Plus is set to have more than 500 movies and 7,500 TV shows. Here's a look at which ones you'll find.See Also:• 10 reasons you should buy the $1,000 iPhone XS instead of the more affordable iPhone XR• Apple is expected to launch 3 new iPhones this year - here's everything we know so far• You've been charging your smartphone all wrongSEE ALSO: 5 critical features the iPhone needs to keep up with AndroidLoad-Date: May 3, 2019End of Document

US spy chiefs used classified info to warn tech execs about doing business with ChinaiCrowdNewswire (English)May 30, 2019 Thursday 10:10 AM GMTCopyright 2019 iCrowdNewswire, LLC All Rights ReservedLength: 452 wordsBody                   US intelligence chiefs have been briefing Silicon Valley tech execs about the possible dangers of doing business in China, according to a report from theFinancial Times. The briefings include warnings about the threat of cyber attacks and the theft of intellectual property, and have been held with groups including tech companies, universities, and venture capitalists in ... Continue reading US spy chiefs used classified info to warn tech execs about doing business with ChinaUS intelligence chiefs have been briefing Silicon Valley tech execs about the possible dangers of doing business in China, according to a report from theFinancial Times.The briefings include warnings about the threat of cyber attacks and the theft of intellectual property, and have been held with groups including tech companies, universities, and venture capitalists in California and Washington.The meetings are the latest example of the US government's increasingly combative stance towards China. In a statement given to the FT, Republican senator Marco Rubio   one of the politicians who organized the briefings   outlined the rationale behind them. It's important that US companies, universities, and trade organizations understand fully that threat.  The Chinese government and Communist party pose the greatest long-term threat to US economic and national security,  said Mr Rubio.  It's important that US companies, universities, and trade organizations understand fully that threat. Those giving the briefings include high-level figures in the US intelligence community such as Dan Coats, director of national intelligence. The meetings also reportedly include the sharing of classified information   an unusual level of disclosure.The FT reports that the briefings began last October. Since then, the trade war between the US and China has escalated dramatically. The most significant intervention came last week, with the White House announcing that US companies will be blocked from buying telecommunications equipment from certain foreign companies including China's Huawei.The Trump administration says this ban is necessary to counter the threat of surveillance and spying from Chinese-made equipment. But the ban is likely to have a big affect on consumers around the world, especially with the news that Google will no longer be able to supply the full version of its Android mobile operating system to Huawei.Tags:  See Campaign:            https://www.theverge.com/2019/5/20/18632236/us-spy-chiefs-brief-silicon-valley-tech-execs-danger-business-chinaContact Information:James VincentTags:,            Artificial Intelligence Newswire,            Wire,            United States,            EnglishLoad-Date: May 30, 2019End of Document

Huawei s security troubles are hardening into a fight between the US and ChinaiCrowdNewswire (English)April 8, 2019 Monday 10:40 AM GMTCopyright 2019 iCrowdNewswire, LLC All Rights ReservedLength: 465 wordsBody                   For months, telecom companies across the world have been struggling with what to do with Huawei. The US has effectively locked the company out of American telecom networks, citing national security concerns   but as the rest of the world faces the same choice, not everyone is convinced Huawei is a threat. Most US experts see Huawei's ... Continue reading Huawei's security troubles are hardening into a fight between the US and ChinaFor months, telecom companies across the world have been struggling with what to do with Huawei. The US has effectively locked the company out of American telecom networks, citing national security concerns   but as the rest of the world faces the same choice, not everyone is convinced Huawei is a threat. Most US experts see Huawei's exposure to the Chinese government as dangerous in itself, but as time has gone on, the national split is getting harder to ignore.This week saw two more prominent figures taking sides, for reasons that seemed more political than technological. On Friday in Geneva, ITU chief Houlin Zhao spoke out publicly against the ban.  If you find anything wrong, then you can charge [Huawei] and accuse them,  Zhao said.  But if we don't have anything then to put them on the blacklist   I think this is not fair.  Zhao was born in China and worked at the government's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications before moving to the UN's telecom union, so it's not surprising that he would be concerned over the lack of evidence against the company.At the same time, US officials are increasingly insistent that all Chinese companies are potentially suspect. At a cybersecurity forum on Thursday, DHS's cybersecurity and infrastructure chief Chris Krebs said the primary concern was the legal regime of the origin country, rather than the specific product being shipped. Our focus is not on the country of origin, or the company, but it's about what is the rule of law under which that product is potentially subject to,  Krebs said. That same logic could apply to other Chinese companies or Russian exports like Kaspersky Lab's antivirus software. As Krebs put it,  it's the rise of authoritarian states and how they're operationalizing their tech sectors. Different readers will sympathize with different sides, but it's getting harder to see how the argument can be resolved with technical analysis. Increasingly, the fight over Huawei looks like a fight between the US and China, with everyone else caught in the middle. And if this week's statements are any indication, it's a fight that will go on and on.Tags:  See Website:            https://www.theverge.com/2019/4/7/18297500/huawei-cyber-us-china-hacking-espionageContact Information:Russell BrandomTags:           Wire,            Artificial Intelligence Newswire,            United States,            EnglishLoad-Date: April 10, 2019End of Document

Continue reading Huawei's security troubles are hardening into a fight between the US and China. The focus isn't on the company, but the legal system that governs itIllustration by William Joel / The VergeFor months, telecom companies across the world have been struggling with what to do with Huawei. The US has effectively locked the company out of American telecom networks, citing national security concerns   but as the rest of the world faces the same choice, not everyone is convinced Huawei is a threat. On Friday in Geneva, ITU chief Houlin Zhao spoke out publicly against the ban.  If you find anything wrong, then you can charge [Huawei] and accuse them,  Zhao said.  But if we don't have anything then to put them on the blacklist   I think this is not fair.  Zhao was born in China and            worked at the government's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications before moving to the UN's telecom union, so it's not surprising that he would be concerned over the lack of evidence against the company.At the same time, US officials are increasingly insistent that all Chinese companies are potentially suspect. At a cybersecurity forum on Thursday, DHS's cybersecurity and infrastructure chief Chris Krebs said the primary concern was the legal regime of the origin country, rather than the specific product being shipped. Our focus is not on the country of origin, or the company, but it's about what is the rule of law under which that product is potentially subject to,  Krebs said. China Is Closing the Innovation Gap With the U.S.USNEWS.comApril 9, 2019 TuesdayCopyright 2019 U.S. News & World Report All Rights ReservedSection: CIVIC; Best Countries; Vol.; No.Length: 475 wordsByline: Sintia RaduHighlight: More than 30 indicators show the Asian country has made tremendous progress in the past decade against the United States.BodyChina is slowly but surely closing the innovation gap with the United States, with the country advancing fast in several innovation categories against the U.S., according to a new            report from the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, or ITIF, a nonprofit public policy think tank based in Washington, D.C. that focuses on technology research. The report looked at 36 indicators related to basic research, research and development (R&D), venture capital or education. [READ:World's Most Innovative Countries by Perception]"(I)n an average of all the indicators, China has cut the gap to the United States by a factor of 1.5 from the base year to the most recent year," say the authors of the report. "For example, had China been 80 percent behind the United States a decade or so ago, it would be just 50 percent behind in the most recent year." Among the study's major findings: -- R&D spending: In 2007 China invested $129 billion investment in R&D, 33 percent less than the United States. By 2017, America's research and development expenditures had grown at a 2 percent annual rate, while China reported a 13.1 percent growth.-- China's basic research expenditure relative to the U.S. doubled between 2007 and 2017 but still lags far behind the reported American figures.-- The Chinese government spends more on R&D as a share of its gross domestic product than the United States, going from spending 84 percent of what the U.S. was reporting in 2007, to spending 1.2 times more than the U.S. in 2017.-- The private sector spends more on R&D in China than in the U.S., but the gap is slowly closing. However, Chinese universities still conduct substantially less research than their American counterparts.-- More than half of the top Chinese companies are now counted among the top 2,500 world innovator's list put together by the European Commission, compared to only 2 percent of them in 2007.-- As a share of its population, China produces almost 50 percent more computer science and engineering degrees than the U.S. The report notes that Hong Kong, an autonomous territory in China that is a global financial center, was included in calculating indicators for China. The report's authors also note the implications of China's innovation progress for other countries. As the other Asian tiger economies of Japan and            South Korea moved from being "copiers to innovators," they took market share away from companies in the U.S. and Europe. Given the size of China's economy, the world's second-largest with projections to eventually overtake the U.S., the Asian giant's rise in innovation will have greater global impact. Sintia Radu covers international affairs and technology for U.S. News & World Report. You can follow her on Twitter            @sintiaradu and send her suggestions and ideas at sradu@usnews.comGraphic Picture, A girl looks at a screen displaying the technology of handwriting in Chengdu, China, on Oct. 9, 2018., (WANG XIAO/GETTY IMAGES)Load-Date: April 10, 2019End of Document

Iran, Trade Expected to be Top Issues During G20 Summit; Waymo, Uber and G.M. Plan Autonomous Service by Year's End; Arby's Introduces Vegetables Made of Meat; Some New York Counties Refusing to Provide Licenses to Illegal ImmigrantsMORNINGS WITH MARIA MORNINGS WITH MARIA 7:00 AM ESTJune 27, 2019 ThursdayCopyright 2019 Fox Business Network LLC All Rights Reserved Section: NEWS; FinancialLength: 7517 wordsByline: Maria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Liz Peek, Juan WilliamsGuests: Siraj Hashmi, Michael Kantrowitz, Paul Bremer, Michael P. We've got that as well, after this break.BARTIROMO: Welcome back.Futures this morning are mixed, take a look. Dow futures down 9 points, S&P futures up 5.25 and the Nasdaq up 22.25. As we've been telling you, the "Wall Street Journal" out with a list of terms that apparently Xi- Jinping is going to be presenting to President Trump this Saturday, as the way to get a deal done.And those terms include lifting the ban on Huawei, lifting all tariffs, as well as the punitive tariffs, be lifted as part of any trade truce. We're talking about that this morning.During my exclusive interview with the President yesterday he said he still wants a cut in interest rates despite a strong economic backdrop.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)BARTIROMO: The economy is doing as well as it is. Hey we're at a 51-year- low on unemployment, 3.1 percent growth in the first quarter. Why do we need interest rates to go lower? Why do we need a cut in rates if things are going so well, Mr. President?DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well, one thing. We have a lot of debt. I want to get it out. I want to pay it off. We have a lot of debt. But what we really have is we're going to stay even with these people.So not only are we raising -- I've had nine interest rate hikes. Obama had nothing. He had cheap money. So my economy is far better than Obama's economy. Obama's economy was ready to crash. You couldn't do anything. The rules and regulations which I've gotten rid off, I have great rules and regulations but they're reasonable. Obama, under Obama, you couldn't do anything.(END VIDEO CLIP)BARTIROMO: And of course that board of futures was yesterday when I was talking with the President that was up 90 points. This morning a very different story.Joining us right now is Michael Kantrowitz of Cornerstone Macro. Michael - - it's good to see you. Thanks so much for being here.MICHAEL KANTROWITZ, CORNERSTONE MACRO: Thank you -- Maria.BARTIROMO: And the President said when talking about a rate cut, we want to get in level with everybody else. He's talking about Europe. Mario Draghi, you know, suggesting that more stimulus is coming, sent the euro lower and makes it real competitive. That's what he's talking about. Do you think we're going to see a rate cut?KANTROWITZ: Yes. It seems the Fed needs to cut rates or at least the market's trying to get the Fed to cut rates. It seems we're probably going to get something less than 50 basis points which the market seems to want. It does seem that Powell and Bollard suggest we're going to see a rate cut sooner than later.BARTIROMO: And you've been expecting things to really slow down. I'm looking at your most recent note where you're telling clients to buckle up for a bad earnings season. We're in the doorstep of the second quarter earnings season. What are you expecting?KANTROWITZ: Yes. We've been seeing global leading indicators now decline for 18 months and leading indicators lead coincident indicators like earnings. And the chart in my report shows how the next couple of earnings seasons, Q2 and Q3 as they get reported were likely to see fewer and fewer companies beat analysts estimates.A year and a half ago. we had two thirds of companies beating estimates last quarter. It was about 50. I'm expecting fewer than half to beat in the next quarter and even less than that in the subsequent quarter following that.PEEK: What do you think that means for the job market?KANTROWITZ: The jobs are also slowing. We have seen leading indicators in the U.S. also declining. It's not just Europe and emerging markets that have been weak and so profits tend to lead job growth and profit growth has been weakening.We think profit growth will be weaker than the street is currently expecting. The Street is still currently expecting 3 percent to 4 percent growth this year and 11 percent growth next year and that's where we think the Street is way too high. But job growth is likely to weaken on the back of weaker profit growth.I think we're also going to see fewer buybacks, less cap ex, less M&A eventually as well. So the liquidity for the Fed may by the lack of liquidity -- the removal of liquidity for the businesses investing and hiring.MCDOWELL: That was really my question -- would a rate cut by the Federal Reserve really stabilize the economy, prevent it from getting worse?KANTROWITZ: I would say that outside of a crisis environment where we've got like an LTCM problem in 1998, or where interest rates are the problem, like the 70s and 80s, it's going to be hard for the fed to cut rates only once and stabilize the economy. They really never have. Usually when the fed is cutting rates, the economy continues to slow for at least another year, which is why you've never seen only one rate cut or only two rate cuts. Usually the feds are cutting rates 200 -- 300 basis points.MCDOWELL: so you're saying we could have an economy that's slowing into the election year.KANTROWITZ: Possibly. We think, though, that leading indicators of the economy, while they've been slowing for about a year and-a-half in the U.S. and now you're starting to see that show up in data like industrial production, job growth and profits, we do think leading indicators could pick up early next year and start to show the signs of some green chutes of a recovery by the time we get later into the year and the election.BARTIROMO: So this morning we've got Boeing taking a hit, news that the FAA found more software issues for the 737 max jet, 2 and a quarter percent -- that's going to impact the broader market. And I like the question that you ask in your note. Your recent report -- you say how long can the market remain resilient as the data continues to weaken.So you look at the impact Boeing has on the market today, let's talk about the impact to all of this that you're talking about it's going to have on the broader market. Is any of this priced in? Do you think market sells off.KANTROWITZ: We do think in the second half the market will sell off. So the overall broad market -- the S&P (INAUDIBLE) index, the Dow Jones Industrials index has really been side ways for about a year and-a-half. We've tried to get back to new highs. We get there and then we kind of have some kind of issue that pulls us back.And so in the beginning of 2018 it was really cyclical stocks that got us to those new highs. And then throughout 2019 this year, it was growth stocks that got us back to the new highs. And as of a few weeks ago, it was really defensive stocks, utilities and REITs that kept us at these new highs.So the rotation within the market has been from value to growth to defense over the last year and-a-half. And that's kept the market resilient. But underneath the surface it's been I think grown weaker than the index suggests.HASHMI: Michael -- do you think it's safe to say that the market and the economy as a whole has peaked.KANTROWITZ: In the near term, we do think it is a fact that leading indicator have peaked. It is a fact that coincident data in terms of the second derivative have peaked. The market does definitely show the telltale signs of a peak, at least -- or potential correction coming up in the second half.BARTIROMO: And just to be clear, you and your colleagues, you're not expecting a China deal right now.KANTROWITZ: No. Andy Le Perrier (ph) our policy analyst at Cornerstone Macro does not believe that we will see a deal until the election.PEEK: What if there were one? Would that change your perspective significantly?KANTROWITZ: If there was a deal that removed a lot of the tariffs that have been put in place, that would certainly help sentiment and I think in the near term, certainly help the market. But at the end of the day, we still think we have to digest the full effect of the tightening cycle we just had from the Fed and that's probably going to stay with us for about another six to nine months.BARTIROMO: When does the Fed cut rates do you think? Later this year?KANTROWITZ: It seems the Fed is setting up -- setting up the market for a cut coming soon, sooner than later -- sooner than later.(CROSSTALK)KANTROWITZ: And I think if they do start to cut rates and if the data does not pick up, we're likely to see many more cuts down the road.BARTIROMO: But if you see a cut in rates, does that send markets higher, does that help what otherwise could have been a selloff for stocks?KANTROWITZ: We don't think so. Periods when the market has gone up when the Fed has been easing had been periods like the early '80s and the early '90s and even 70's where interest rates were really high and they were a problem. So by the Fed cutting rates or rates falling in general, that helped the market. Today we don't have a high rates problem. We have a growth problem which can't be turned around with one or two rate cuts.MCDOWELL: I think when the Federal Reserve cut rates it was in early 2001 in January, it was a surprise cut after the NASDAQ had already peaked. The NASDAQ had its best one day performance ever in one day, it was a double digit gain in one day and it then right after that continued this crash.KANTROWITZ: Yes.BARTIROMO: So is there anywhere to hide, Michael? Real quick before you go, I mean, you're painting a picture of a slowing economy, potentially market selloff as a result of that, no help from the Fed even if we were to see a cut, anywhere to hide? I mean, anything -- what do you recommend?KANTROWITZ: We've been recommending a more defensive posture for investors and that's being even extended now into gold prices, we're seeing break out, even Bitcoin. The investors are looking for things that are not cyclically sensitive to the economy, and that are not sensitive to the trade or even the Fed. So we've been recommending utilities, healthcare, staples, real estate, gold. It's really a defensive assets and we think investors want to park their money there for about another six to nine months and then we do expect to see things improve early next year.BARTIROMO: All right, Michael, great insights. Thanks so much.KANTROWITZ: You bet.BARTIROMO: Michael Kantrowitz from Cornerstone Macro this morning.Coming up, President Trump is at the G20 summit, what he's being asked ahead of the crucial trade meeting with China's president, next.BARTIROMO: Welcome back. One of the clerks is with us this morning, live.Starbucks losing money overseas. This as the coffee giant introduces new drinks for the summertime. We will tell you about that.And Arby's takes a shot at meatless burgers. Check this out, the fast food chain has a vegetable but it's really made of meat. It looks like a vegetable. Make you feel better about yourself, I guess.Breaking news this last half an hour, President Trump arriving in Japan for the G20 summit. And China President Xi Jinping is going to be armed with terms for the president before they agree to any deal. In fact, Xi Jinping is expected to insist that President Trump lift the ban on Huawei as part of a U.S.-China trade deal, this is according to the Wall Street Journal this morning. The Journal also reports that Xi Jinping is going to say to do away with all of the punitive tariffs and do not insist that the Chinese buy excessive -- number of goods from the United States.Now, there are crucial meetings on trades taking center stage. Yesterday in an exclusive interview, I spoke with President Trump about the recent tensions and the threat from Iran.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)BARTIROMO: Are we going to have a war with Iran, Mr. President?TRUMP: Well, I hope we don't. But we're in a very strong position if we have something should happen, we're in a very strong position. It wouldn't last very long, I can tell you that.BARTIROMO: The sanctions are enough in your view to fight back on Iran's provocations?TRUMP: Well, the sanction is a very biding. When I took over, Iran was a terror. We had 18 to 14 to 18 sites of confliction. Iran was behind every one of them. Look at what -- they were going to take over the Middle East and they were going to make it really very, very bad.(END VIDEO CLIP)BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is the former presidential envoy to Iraq, former National Commissioner (ph) on Terrorism Chairman and former ambassador to the Netherlands, Paul Bremer. Sir, good to have you on the program this morning. Thanks so much for joining me.PAUL BREMER, FORMER CHAIRMAN, NATIONAL COMMISSION ON TERRORISM: Nice to be with you, Maria.BARTIROMO: So what is your reaction to what we've seen from Iran these last couple of weeks and what do you think the U.S.'s response should be?BREMER: Well, let's start by recognizing, the Persians have been at the game of empire for thousands of years. They know a thing or two about their location and their geography. And I think if I were in their shoes, I would be confused by what the American policy is on two key points. The question of regime change and the question that you asked the president about the use of military force. I think they have a right to be somewhat confused about what our policy really is. And that's potentially dangerous.BARTIROMO: Do you mean because we pulled out of the Iran deal?BREMER: No, the key problem is the president has said that we don't seek regime change. The Secretary of State has said he wants Iran to be a normal country and we're ready for what secretary called unconditional talks, but then he listed 12 conditions. Only three of which related to the Iran nuclear deal. Nine others effectively said to the Iranians we want you to change your regime. So, there's a real question about that.Then, on the use of force, the president after the turnaround last week about whether we would hit or not hit the radar site that brought down our drone, sent out a tweet saying if Iran attacks anything American, anything, not any Americans, anything American, our response will be overwhelming even to obliteration. That suggests a willingness to use force and in effect to go to war. Then he -- his Secretary of Defense said, just a day later, we are not going to war with Iran. Which means is it off the table then? Is military response off the table despite what the president said?So, you know, in a war, there's something to be said for spreading confusion in the enemy camp. But if you're trying to avoid a war, in diplomacy, a certain degree of precision and clarity is needed and I don't think we're certainly not any way in the public domain, we're not being very clear.BARTIROMO: Right.PEEK: Ambassador, question for you. Thank you for joining us this morning. What do you think should be the off-ramp for Iran? In other words, we have to give them some way to get back to the negotiating table which is not a total humiliation or repudiation of the JCPOA or whatever past agreements we've had. What do you think could be a path forward?BREMER: Well, I rather optimistically as it turned out thought that the president's decision not to carry out the attack might have been a signal to the Iranians that there was an off-ramp and one could hope that there are back channeled communications going on right now between the Swiss that represent us in Tehran or between the Omanis who have traditionally been a very good third party area.But with the sanctioning of the Supreme Leader and the -- and the Iranian Foreign Minister, I'm not sure that we've offered any off-ramps at this point. It's very different -- and this is -- I mean, this is how unintentional wars get started. When you're not being very clear, at least in private, as to what the red lines really are.HASHMI: Ambassador, do you think President Trump has done a pretty decent job of at least holding some of the hoax in his administration like Secretary Pompeo and National Security adviser John Bolton at bay here?BREMER: Well, I don't find it very profitable to speculate on the internal debates within the administration. And I don't think the Iranians do either. I think the Iranians will pay attention to the kind of confusing messages that I refer to both on the question of regime change and on the question of the use of force.And you know, it was 150 years ago tomorrow that basically century of war descended on Europe when the Europeans were unable to deal with a minor crisis, which was the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo, exactly at a 150 years ago tomorrow. This is a dangerous thing to be -- a dangerous situation to find ourselves in. Now, again, --BARTIROMO: So, you'd like to see more clarity -- you'd like to see clarity on regime change as -- and what the U.S. administration wants, as well as the potential for military force? Obviously they're not going to spell out what they may or may not do on military force but I understand your point on the regime change.BREMER: Yes, I think there needs to be more clarity at a minimum in whatever we're saying privately to the Iranians, and we have channels. We have channels through the Europeans, the Japanese, he'll be seeing, Abe. Abe was just in Tehran. He got stiffed because he brought a message that the president wanted to have a communication with Ayatollah Khomeini and Khomeini publicly while Abe was sitting there, saying I'm not interested in having a conversation with Trump. But we have -- he has channels that he can exploit while he's in Osaka, if that's something he wants to do.BARTIROMO: Ambassador, thank you. Great insights from you and we appreciate you joining us this morning.BREMER: Nice to be with you, Maria.BARTIROMO: Paul Bremer joining us there. Coming up, Uber is under pressure this morning, drivers organizing north of the border. We've got those details.And then Arby's taking on the meatless trend. What do you think is behind that law, first off?KEARNS: Probably more voters. But for me, my opposition is dealing with the conflict with federal law. Right now, this creates an obstacle for our federal law enforcement to do their jobs, to prevent illegals from being here. It prevents conflict for the clerks. It puts them in a precarious situation because do we file state law or federal law?And look at yesterday, the other day, we had an Orleans county bus by ICE that took some illegal aliens that were working on the firm and they had false documents. They were in federal court yesterday. That was a religious opinion on her part. We're going into federal court. We're preparing our paperwork and we're going on the rule of law.Remember, in New York State now they have to be notified, ICE has to be notified and that illegal alien gets a three-day notification if there's a judicial warrant pulled out against them. And that's something that an average citizen, a united citizen doesn't get. So, this is all about the rule of law.BARTIROMO: Yes, I know, I think you make great points, Michael. Trump vs. Huawei: the empire strikes backCE Noticias Financieras EnglishMay 24, 2019 FridayCopyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.All Rights ReservedCopyright 2019 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights ReservedLength: 1004 wordsBody You buy a luxury or compact vehicle and the next day finds out by the means that the manufacturer will no longer have spare parts or maintenance. After the initial shock, you will most likely seek to get rid of that car as soon as possible and never buy that brand again. That is the perception of the millions of users of Huawei devices, that is the intention of the United States government to include said Chinese manufacturer in the black list of the Department of Commerce of the American Union. But what does not kill, strengthens.  President Donald Trump signed an Executive Order declaring a national emergency! ensure and protect from foreign threats and adversaries the supply chain of information and communication technologies and services. Let's recognize Trump's strategic vision of digital networks for the immediate future of the US and global economy. The US Department of Justice accuses Huawei, "the largest manufacturer of telecommunications equipment," of bank fraud, electronic fraud and trade relations with Iran.  Now the sale or transfer of US technology to Huawei requires a license issued by the Department of Industry and Security of the Department of Commerce, that is, the manufacturers and / or developers of US technology can not provide (by effect of the Executive Order) equipment, solutions or technological services to the Chinese consortium.  Google was the first to suspend the transfer of software, hardware and services to Huawei. (Qualcomm, Intel and other companies and operators joined the ban). That means that future devices of the Chinese manufacturer will lack the Android operating system, popular Google applications and their updates.  According to the Justice Department statement, "the government investigation is ongoing," that is, there is still no sentence. Huawei has also been accused by the US of spying for the Chinese government via telecommunications networks, in alleged compliance with China's State Security Law, which requires companies and individuals in that country to "provide assistance with related work." with the security of the State. "  For this second accusation, the US has not provided any evidence that there are really risks of cybersecurity, back doors or Huawei espionage actions through their teams in favor of the Chinese regime. The US has put pressure on several countries so that future deployments of 5G networks do not include hardware or software from the Chinese supplier, "for security reasons". Without evidence, several nations have folded to Trump's mandate, but others like Germany or France have resisted and proposed alternatives to "manage cybersecurity risk."  According to Counterpoint, as of March 2019, 17% of smartphones in the world were Huawei, second only to Samsung (21%) and above Apple (12%). A year earlier, the Chinese manufacturer's market share was 11% (and 5% in the first quarter of 2015), positioning itself as the fastest growing manufacturer and, therefore, as a threat to its competitors . In the Chinese smartphone market, Huawei is the undisputed leader with 29% (1Q19). In Europe it occupies the second position with 26% market share. In Latin America, Huawei enjoys 13.2% market share, behind Samsung (36.6%) and Motorola (14.9%) (3Q18).  These figures reveal the immense disproportion of Google's decision to restrict its software and apps to Huawei. A reverse reading suggests that the Executive Order does not measure Huawei's security risks but the size and colossal power of Internet companies such as Google. The measure seeks to exclude Huawei and the users of its gadgets from the digital ecosystem supported by mobile operating systems. Atbetter, with Huawei will be born a third operating system (HongMeng OS?) behind Apple's Android and iOS, important for the Huawei market share but not for its influence or social roots. There is Tizen, the other Samsung operating system that failed, but that glimpsed the risk of dependence on Android.  Trump's Executive Order, unintentionally, placed the reflectors on Google as "owner" of the global digital switch, capable of disconnecting, shutting down and expelling millions of users of systems, applications and services, when what is spoken at the level of public policies is digital inclusion. We are facing one of the attacks on the right of access to the most enormous ICTs due to its global reach.  The philosophy of Huawei, both in consumer devices and in computer systems and telecommunications networks, is summarized in one sentence: "the same but cheaper". This commercial strategy is the result of a "socialist market economy" or "socialism with Chinese characteristics" that promotes accelerated growth. The President of China, Xi Jinping, proclaimed in 2013 the "Chinese Dream" and set a short-term goal to achieve that in 2021 the Chinese society live at least modestly well-off.  International organizations, governments of the world, regulators, universities and research centers and large technology companies (especially an innovative and avant-garde Sillicon Valley) should not allow the empire to make decisions and affect the digital life of millions of people. people with irreversible effects, without evidence and without firm sentences. The US has previously lied, for example, to justify the second invasion of Iraq in 2003, due to alleged weapons of mass destruction that were never found nor its existence demonstrated. Do you believe Trump?  The accusations against Huawei should serve to implement a global collaboration framework that allows creating and sharing cybersecurity standards for future 5G networks. Also, the Chinese government has already delayed in suppressing that fragment of its Law of State Security that forces to collaborate with the communist regime: it is affecting its own companies. Later we will know if this attack kills or strengthens Huawei, and if the war that already started is between countries or between Internet territories to create a new (des) digital order. Twitter : @beltmondi Load-Date: May 24, 2019End of Document

Six minutes of sex and gore cut from Game of Thrones season premiere in ChinaCNN.comApril 16, 2019 Tuesday 5:03 AM ESTCopyright 2019 Cable News Network All Rights ReservedSection: SHOWBIZLength: 267 wordsByline: By Yong Xiong and Ben Westcott, CNNDateline: Beijing BodyChina-based fans of "Game of Thrones" missed out on six minutes of violence, prostitutes and coarse language which was cut from the premiere of the show's final season on Sunday.Chinese media giant Tencent owns the exclusive rights to the widely loved HBO series inside the country, where it can be watched on the company's website and app.HBO itself is not available to the general public there, leaving the censored version on Tencent as the only legal option.The first episode of season 8 was broadcast around the world Sunday night. The hit fantasy show explores the bloody feuds of noble families as they struggle to gain the Iron Throne in the fictional world of Westeros.The series is famous for its violence and nudity -- but Chinese fans have learned to expect strict censorship.Without spoiling the plot of the first episode, the moments cut include a sex scene with prostitutes, close-up shots of people being killed with arrows and an ax, and one instance of a character swearing.A blogger on the movie review website Douban suggested viewers should file a "group lawsuit" against Tencent for the cuts, while others made their anger known on Chinese social media site Weibo."I'm not unwilling to pay Tencent for this show, but how can I watch when they cut so many scenes? I'll have to download the video from the internet eventually," one user said.It is unknown whether the censorship was carried out by the Chinese government, Tencent prior to airing or preemptively by HBO itself.CNN has asked HBO, Tencent and the government for comment. HBO is part of CNN's parent company WarnerMedia.Load-Date: April 17, 2019End of Document

Six minutes of sex and gore cut from Game of Thrones season premiere in ChinaCNN WireApril 16, 2019 Tuesday 9:03 AM GMTCopyright 2019 Cable News Network All Rights ReservedLength: 283 wordsByline: By Yong Xiong and Ben Westcott, CNNDateline: BEIJING (CNN) BodyBEIJING (CNN) --  China-based fans of "Game of Thrones" missed out on six minutes of violence, prostitutes and coarse language which was cut from the premiere of the show's final season on Sunday.Chinese media giant Tencent owns the exclusive rights to the widely loved HBO series inside the country, where it can be watched on the company's website and app.HBO itself is not available to the general public there, leaving the censored version on Tencent as the only legal option.The first episode of season 8 was broadcast around the world Sunday night. The hit fantasy show explores the bloody feuds of noble families as they struggle to gain the Iron Throne in the fictional world of Westeros.The series is famous for its violence and nudity -- but Chinese fans have learned to expect strict censorship.Without spoiling the plot of the first episode, the moments cut include a sex scene with prostitutes, close-up shots of people being killed with arrows and an ax, and one instance of a character swearing.A blogger on the movie review website Douban suggested viewers should file a "group lawsuit" against Tencent for the cuts, while others made their anger known on Chinese social media site Weibo."I'm not unwilling to pay Tencent for this show, but how can I watch when they cut so many scenes? I'll have to download the video from the internet eventually," one user said.It is unknown whether the censorship was carried out by the Chinese government, Tencent prior to airing or preemptively by HBO itself. CNN has asked HBO, Tencent and the government for comment. HBO is part of CNN's parent company WarnerMedia.TM & © 2019 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. All rights reserved.Load-Date: April 17, 2019End of Document

China's LGBT community excited by Pete Buttigieg's presidential runCNN.comApril 15, 2019 Monday 11:57 AM ESTCopyright 2019 Cable News Network All Rights ReservedSection: ASIALength: 808 wordsByline: By Steven Jiang, CNNDateline: Beijing BodyWith the official launch of his presidential campaign Sunday, Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, is pitching to become the first openly gay US President in history.That prospect -- albeit still a long shot -- is attracting the growing attention of LGBT communities around the world, including in China where experts and activists say sexual minorities face persistent discrimination as well as periodic government crackdowns.There has been no coverage of Buttigieg on China's strictly controlled state media, but some LGBT community leaders are following the Democratic hopeful, whose unexpected rise in the past weeks has dominated US political news, in overseas media."I know he's 37 years old, once the youngest mayor in America, an Afghanistan war veteran and a Harvard graduate," said Xiaogang Wei, a leading LGBT rights advocate in China who heads the Beijing Gender Health Education Institute."Any openly gay world leader is good news in terms of raising LGBT visibility," he added. "But a gay US President would bring so much global visibility and that would be a very positive development for LGBT communities around the world."LGBT censorshipHomosexuality is not illegal in China and the authorities removed it from the official list of mental disorders in 2001. But in recent years, the Communist government under President Xi Jinping has taken an increasingly hardline stance on LGBT rights, banning portrayal of same-sex relationships on television and online.In March, most mentions of homosexuality were removed from "Bohemian Rhapsody," the award-winning biopic of British rock band Queen's frontman Freddie Mercury, prior to its release in China.Among the clips that were removed were scenes of men kissing and the word "gay" for the Chinese audience.While expressing their excitement over Buttigieg's candidacy, activists in China say there is a scarcity of Chinese-language information on him. The Chinese social media posts on Buttigieg that do exist appear to have so far drawn largely admiring and supportive reactions, mixed with occasional homophobic comments."When the US legalized same-sex marriage nationwide, it triggered an outpouring of discussions and soul-searching on LGBT rights in China for weeks," said Hua Zile, founder of the "Voice of China LGBT," a social media page with more than a million followers on Weibo, China's equivalent of Twitter."If (Buttigieg) gets elected, it would undoubtedly have a very positive effect on us," he said, adding his site would like to translate and share more articles on the candidate.'Imagine Xi having to meet Buttigieg'Buttigieg has not shied away from talking about this sexuality, recounting his struggles to come out, highlighting his marriage to high school teacher Chasten Glezman, and feuding with conservative US Vice President Mike Pence on the relationship between one's religious faith and stance on LGBT rights.But the young mayor has stressed that he is not running for any one group, quipping in an interview last week: "If I thought to myself just in terms of identity lines, it'd be a pretty lonely place, because I'm the only Maltese-American Episcopalian gay veteran that I know."Some of Buttigieg's Chinese fans, however, wish to see the spotlight on his sexuality stay on so that China's leaders would eventually be forced to face up to a topic that they have long shunned publicly."Imagine Xi having to meet Buttigieg and his husband," said Billy Zhao, a gay Chinese millennial who has lived in Washington on and off for the past eight years.At least two openly gay Western leaders -- the prime ministers of Iceland and Luxembourg -- have visited China in the past decade, but their same-sex spouses were nowhere to be mentioned in state media reports."Most Chinese people, especially those from my parents' and grandparents' generations, are still very ignorant of homosexuality," said Zhao, an energy consultant. "I think Americans electing a gay President would have a great impact on their mentality, with all the news coverage opening a conversation on the subject."Zhao has been sending his friends in China links to videos of Buttigieg's interviews and speeches, only to see his effort thwarted by the fact that YouTube has long been blocked by the Beijing government.Some Chinese advocates for LGBT rights have also noticed Buttigieg's lack of specific policy positions, a growing complaint from his US critics as he quickly gains name recognition and rises in polls."I still don't know much about his governing philosophy," said Wei, the Beijing activist. "I want to find out how he plans to engage civil societies in the rest of the world and make the US a role model.""Being a gay President could be a double-edged sword," he cautioned. "I could see forces hostile to LGBT people blaming his sexuality for certain policy failures."Load-Date: April 16, 2019End of Document

China's LGBT community excited by Pete Buttigieg's presidential runCNN WireApril 15, 2019 Monday 8:12 AM GMTCopyright 2019 Cable News Network All Rights ReservedLength: 812 wordsByline: By Steven Jiang, CNNDateline: BEIJING (CNN) BodyBEIJING (CNN) --  With the official launch of his presidential campaign Sunday, Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, is pitching to become the first openly gay US President in history.That prospect -- albeit still a long shot -- is attracting the growing attention of LGBT communities around the world, including in China where experts and activists say sexual minorities face persistent discrimination as well as periodic government crackdowns.There has been no coverage of Buttigieg on China's strictly controlled state media, but some LGBT community leaders are following the Democratic hopeful, whose unexpected rise in the past weeks has dominated US political news, in overseas media."I know he's 37 years old, once the youngest mayor in America, an Afghan war veteran and a Harvard graduate," said Xiaogang Wei, a leading LGBT rights advocate in China who heads the Beijing Gender Health Education Institute."Any openly gay world leader is good news," he added. "But a gay US President would bring so much global visibility and that would be a very positive development for LGBT communities around the world."LGBT censorshipHomosexuality is not illegal in China and the authorities removed it from the official list of mental disorders in 2001. But in recent years the government under President Xi Jinping has taken an increasingly hardline stance on LGBT rights, banning portrayal of same-sex relationships on television and online.In March, most mentions of homosexuality were removed from "Bohemian Rhapsody," the award-winning biopic of British rock band Queen's frontman Freddie Mercury, prior to its release in China.Among the clips which were removed were scenes of men kissing and the word "gay" for the Chinese audience.While expressing their excitement over Buttigieg's candidacy, activists in China say there is a scarcity of Chinese-language information on him. The Chinese social media posts on Buttigieg which do exist appear to have so far drawn largely admiring and supportive reactions, mixed with occasional homophobic comments."When the US legalized same-sex marriage nationwide, it triggered an outpouring of discussions and soul-searching on LGBT rights in China for weeks," said Hua Zile, founder of the "Voice of China LGBT," a social media page with more than a million followers on Weibo, China's equivalent of Twitter."If (Buttigieg) gets elected, it would undoubtedly have a very positive effect on us," he said, adding his site would like to translate and share more articles on the candidate.'Imagine Xi having to meet Buttigieg'Buttigieg has not shied away from talking about this sexuality, recounting touching stories of his struggles to come out and feuding with conservative US Vice President Mike Pence on the relationship between one's religious faith and stance on LGBT rights.But the young mayor has stressed that he is not running for any one group, quipping in an interview last week: "If I thought to myself just in terms of identity lines, it'd be a pretty lonely place, because I'm the only Maltese-American Episcopalian gay veteran that I know."Some of Buttigieg's Chinese fans, however, wish to see the spotlight on his sexuality stay on so that China's leaders would eventually be forced to face up to a topic that they have long shunned publicly."Imagine Xi having to meet Buttigieg and his husband," said Billy Zhao, a millennial gay Chinese native who has lived in Washington on and off in the past eight years.At least two openly gay Western leaders -- prime ministers of Iceland and Luxembourg -- have visited China in the past decade, but their accompanying same-sex spouses were nowhere to be seen in state media reports and videos."Most Chinese people, especially those from my parents' and grandparents' generations, are still very ignorant of homosexuality," said Zhao, an energy consultant. "I think Americans electing a gay President would have a great impact on their mentality, with all the news coverage opening a conversation on the subject."Zhao has been sending his friends in China links to videos of Buttigieg's interviews and speeches, only to see his effort thwarted by the fact that YouTube has long been blocked by the Beijing government.Some Chinese advocates for LGBT rights have also noticed Buttigieg's lack of specific policy positions, a growing complaint from his US critics as he quickly gains name recognition and rises in polls."I still don't know much about his governing philosophy," said Wei, the Beijing activist. "I want to find out how he plans to engage civil societies in the rest of the world and make the US a role model.""Being a gay President could be a double-edged sword," he cautioned. "I could see forces hostile to LGBT people blaming his (sexuality) for certain policy failures."TM & © 2019 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. All rights reserved.Load-Date: April 16, 2019End of Document

14 seconds of undercover footage reveals the shadowy, sinister reality of China's 21st-century police stateBusiness Insider USJune 27, 2019 Thursday 01:26 PM GMTCopyright 2019 Insider Inc. All Rights ReservedLength: 930 wordsByline: ama@businessinsider.com,  (Alexandra Ma)Highlight: China is severely cracking down the Uighurs, a Muslim ethnic minority in the country's west. Beijing claims they are national-security threats.BodyT. Wang / VICE News Tonight• Xinjiang, a frontier region in China's west, is the most oppressed area in China.• Authorities in the region are spying on and arbitrarily arresting people from the Muslim Uighur minority population and, in many cases, torturing and detaining them in prison-like camps.• VICE News published eerie undercover footage of eight Uighur men being marched down to a local police station. Its documentary on Xinjiang publishes Thursday night.• Watch the clip below.• Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.Eight young men, wearing dark clothing, are marching in complete silence down a busy city street.They are striding almost in unison toward a police station, where they will likely face hours of intense questioning and risk being sent away to what's called a "re-education camp." People who get sent there are locked away, with no idea of when they might get out.This is the scene in VICE News's new documentary on the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, the most oppressed in the country. This particular scene - which takes up 14 chilling seconds in the 30-minute documentary - was taken by two undercover reporters around 12:30 a.m. in Hotan, a bustling town in southwestern Xinjiang.The men were marched for around four minutes, according to VICE News. Watch a clip of the moment below.Youtube Embed: //www.youtube.com/embed/p-VIGznQB14 Width: 560px Height: 315px We know the danger that the men in the video face not because we know their names, or can see their faces, but because they are Uighurs - the majority-Muslim ethnic minority currently under unprecedented scrutiny and surveillance by the Chinese government.Read more: This map shows a trillion-dollar reason why China is oppressing more than a million MuslimsIsobel Yeung, the VICE News correspondent who posed as a travel blogger to capture the video, tweeted that visiting Xinjiang was the "hardest, most harrowing story" she has ever worked on.Kevin Frayer/Getty ImagesThough Beijing has cracked down on Uighur activity since 2009, when a series of ethnic riots took place across the country, it only recently started ramping up its high-tech surveillance operation, and handing out sterner punishments to the people.This 21st-century police state involves installing close to one million facial recognition cameras across the region, making Uighurs download spyware on their phones, and holding at least one million Uighurs in prison-like detention centers.Former detainees have described having to sing patriotic songs in order to get food, and being both physically and mentally tortured.Read more: What it's like inside the internment camps China uses to oppress its Muslim minority, according to people who've been thereBen Blanchard/ReutersBeijing characterizes all Uighurs as terrorists, and has routinely tried to stoke Islamophobia and cite national security concerns to justify its actions in the region.Authorities have imposed a variety of oppressive laws in the region, including asking tech companies to block and report the transfer of any content that might seem unsavory to the regime.It has also been reported that authorities have arrested people for refusing to drink alcohol or            setting their watch two hours behind Beijing Standard Time to            adhere to natural daylight hours in Xinjiang.Read more: China uses an intrusive surveillance app to track its Muslim minority, with technology that could be exported to the rest of the world. Here's how it works.Reuters/PoolUighurs - who refer to Xinjiang as East Turkestan - believe that China is trying to eradicate their culture. Beijing says it is unifying the Chinese nation.Authorities in the region have also started detaining Uighurs even if they haven't committed a crime. They say it's to prevent them from doing so.Zhang Zhisheng, a top official at the Xinjiang Foreign Affairs Office, told the BBC in a recent interview: "Some people, before they commit murder, already show they're capable of killing. Should we wait for them to commit the crime? Or should we prevent it from happening?"OZAN KOSE/AFP/Getty ImagesThe plight of the Uighurs has captured international attention, with The New York Times having featured a story about Xinjiang above the fold of its front page at least once over the past year.The US has criticized China over its human rights record in Xinjiang, with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo particularly vocal.But the White House has so far ignored repeated calls by several Democratic and Republican members of Congress to impose sanctions on human-rights offenders in Xinjiang.Muslim-majority countries, such as Pakistan, have also refused to speak out against the Uighur atrocities. Many analysts say it's because they don't want to incur Beijing's wrath, and lose out on their beneficial economic relationship with China.Read more: A wave of Islamic countries started to stand up to China over its persecution of its Muslim minority. But then they all got spooked.Watch a trailer to the VICE News documentary below. The full version comes out on HBO at 7:30 p.m. ET, and on YouTube at 8 p.m. ET.Youtube Embed: //www.youtube.com/embed/wDjwuQ_TfyU Width: 560px Height: 315pxNOW WATCH: The incredible story behind Slack, the app that's taken over offices everywhereSee Also:• Maps from US and Iran give contradictory locations for US drone that got shot down• Video appears to show Iran missile launcher blasting US drone out of the sky• Iran claims Trump tipped it off that a military strike was imminent - despite reports suggesting the US ultimately backed downLoad-Date: June 27, 2019End of
